author: {'steamid': '76561198967520108', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1704542573}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG is a delightful homage to 80s pop culture and classic role-playing games developed by Mighty Rabbit Studios. Originally released in 2012, this indie gem offers a nostalgic trip down memory lane, combining retro aesthetics with modern gameplay mechanics to create a charming and entertaining experience.

Set in a world inspired by Saturday morning cartoons and 80s pop culture references, Saturday Morning RPG follows the adventures of Marty, an ordinary high school student who gains extraordinary powers after receiving a magical trapper keeper. Armed with his newfound abilities, Marty embarks on a quest to thwart the sinister plans of the evil Commander Hood and his minions.

One of the standout features of Saturday Morning RPG is its presentation. The game's pixel art graphics and chiptune soundtrack perfectly capture the look and feel of classic 8-bit and 16-bit era RPGs, evoking a sense of nostalgia for players who grew up with retro gaming consoles. From the colorful character designs to the catchy music, every aspect of Saturday Morning RPG oozes charm and personality.

In terms of gameplay, Saturday Morning RPG offers a mix of turn-based combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving. Players must navigate through various levels, engaging in battles with enemies using a unique battle system that combines timing-based mechanics with traditional RPG elements. The game also features a variety of collectibles and side quests to discover, adding depth and replay value to the experience.

Beyond its gameplay mechanics, Saturday Morning RPG is packed with clever references and Easter eggs that pay homage to classic cartoons, movies, and video games from the 80s and 90s. From nods to iconic characters like He-Man and Optimus Prime to parodies of famous movie scenes, the game is filled with moments that will bring a smile to the faces of retro enthusiasts.

While Saturday Morning RPG may not offer the same level of depth or complexity as some other RPGs, its charm, humor, and nostalgic appeal more than make up for it. Whether you're a fan of classic role-playing games or simply looking for a fun and lighthearted adventure, Saturday Morning RPG is sure to provide hours of entertainment for players of all ages.

review:
I wish I could give this game a neutral review.

Pros:
+ Interesting concept
+ References to many cartoons from the 80's 
+ Story is generally good
+ Many collectables to encourage exploration

Cons:
- Unfinished story as there's no episode 6
- You have to scratch stickers before each battle to get bonuses
- You have to charge every attack before use

Overall I had fun but this game has several major drawbacks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008788094', 'num_games_owned': 1695, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 797, 'last_played': 1692990992}
review:
TL, DR: Its a nice short game for 80s fans that are okay with some repetitive combat and cheesy sadly unfinished storyline.

A fun jrpg style game, full of 80¬¥s pop culture references. Its like if a 80`s kid had a fever dream where pretty much all of media characters became reality (atleast parodies of them). 

The music (which was made by people who made the soundtrack for major 80s franchises) and the graphics are great and really make it feel like a movies of that decade. The combat starts out cool, but once you sort out the best items from the lesser ones (or completely useless joke ones) youll be using those mostly, trying to get good parries and doing the minigames (or just picking items that dont need them) and healing. It does get repetetive, and there is not that many types of enemies. 

The game is short for an RPG, the 13 hours was me trying to do every quest and get every item (I know there is atleast one secret optional superboss, for which you need to replay the episodes, I may get back to that later) you could do it in shorter time. The story is incomplete the makers wanted probably to do more content but the money dried up, or not enough was made in sales. Sad because the game has potential, but the minor bugs and lack of a conclusion of the story bug me a bit, however I think it still deserves a recommend, however its not for everyone.

 If you are someone that enjoys 80s media like me, youll have fun at the paperthin parodies of characters that you know and some more obscure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 548, 'playtime_forever': 1788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1381, 'last_played': 1670511837}
review:
*Note that 1 achievement is broken in the latest build.

[b]My Playtime:[/b] 23h (86/87 achievement, finished the game)
[b]My First Playthrough:[/b] 7.4h
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (14 achievements).
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (80 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Saturday Morning RPG[/b] is a turn-based RPG that takes homage to old cartoons, shown in an episodic style with a bad guy that you need to beat in each of them. There are 5 episodes in total.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 5 episodes
- Customizable enemy level
- Main quest and side quest markers make it easier to track quests

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Scratching stickers become annoying as you continue playing the game
- The game always shows keyboard controls despite you choosing controller controls at the beginning
- No skip cutscene options for episode replays

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you grow up with the 80s-90s cartoon and don't mind the visuals and grind, buy it when it's on sale.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
The visuals need some time to get used to. It tries to combine 3D environments with 2D, pixelated sprites, which obviously look weird whenever the game tries to show the character from up close - you'll only see them in a more pixelated, "blurry" state. The environments are also not particularly engaging, but again, you'll get used to it.

[h3]Story[/h3]
As I said before, the game takes inspiration from old weekly cartoons, which might be where the title comes from. It is episodic in nature; you'll have a bad guy of the "week" and some repeated plot about the final boss that wants to crush our main protagonist at the end of the episode. However, the plot takes a weird turn in the last episode, forcing some bad guys to be good and giving us a wall of text to explain their reasoning. This feels weird and forced as a result; the shows that they take homage to are always meant to be light in nature, and it doesn't match with the intended audience this way.

The game also has a lot of references to other works. I don't think I catch everything since I didn't grow up in the same area as the intended audience, but I could find some homage to shows like [b]Transformers[/b] and [b]Dragon Ball[/b]. The notebook with stickers and baseball cards might also hold some value to some extent, but since there is never such a thing in my place, I couldn't be sure whether it was truly the case.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=491489275

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
The game was an RPG at its core. You will have the main objective and some optional side quests that you can get from talking to other people. It's mostly linear, although areas are huge enough with some episodes giving you some room for exploration. Some enemies will also be placed in the area, but they are limited in number and don't respawn. This makes it easier to focus on the other aspects of the game once; some areas can be confusing to navigate unless you paid full attention to them. Points of returns are also clearly specified, making it easy to navigate without worrying about missing out.

Quests have a direction marker to them. Sometimes, it's hard to figure out where to go next, especially the side quests since you need to remember who everyone is to progress. The addition of the marker helps to circumvent that issue, although sadly, it's kinda buggy. Some quests, especially those in episode 5, don't have any markers, and sometimes they don't even point in the right direction.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=642171846

Scratching stickers might look cool at first, but it will just tire you out as you progress. You have a list of stickers that you can collect, which will give you bonuses in battle whenever you manage to scratch it. Scratching is done by circling your left analog button, but since you need to do it quickly to scratch the difficult ones, it can be hard to do it on the keyboard. Moreover, it also can be tiring to keep on scratching it after a few battles and the stat boosts aren't needed to beat the enemies.

There are a lot of weapons in the game, but most of them are useless. Status effects like paralyze and stun might help to prevent a lot of enemies from attacking you, but they prove to be of no value once you find out that enemies die in 2-3 hits. Weapons with multi-hits and multi-targets have low accuracy and/or damage, making it hard to find their uses. There seem to be only a few weapons that work properly, forcing you to play in a specific playstyle to beat the game.

[b]Combat[/b]
Combat depends on your weapon choice. Some weapons will force you to do QTE, but you also can choose the ones without it with the risk of losing some damage. There is also a multiplier that you can boost by charging, which again, is more effective with QTE. You'll find yourself being in a repetitive loop of increasing your multiplier and unleashing your highest damaging move due to its simplicity.

Enemies might hit you, but you can time your defense at the right time to reduce it. The window to perfectly defend against the attack is small, but the game is kind enough to give some sort of protection even if you press the button very early. Some enemies might give you some trouble, forcing you to prioritize them. However, I only found one enemy of that kind in the game. On the good side, your HP and MP will be restored after each fight, so you don't have to worry about healing.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=885485188

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished all episodes in 7.4h. The rest of my playtime was spent obtaining all achievements, although sadly, one of them is broken - it unlocked in the game for me, but not in Steam. As for difficulty, the game isn't hard if you don't mind grinding. You might be able to screw yourself up if you build your status recklessly, but there are always the sticker powerups that can help you. Plus, there is one weapon that can make you invisible by spending some in-game money.

[b]Issues[/b]
There is no skip cutscene for second replays. The game seems to enforce you to replay the game to experience all choices in some of its side quests, but you have to deal with the cutscenes over and over again. Luckily, they are short and you just need to spam the interact button to skip them. Moreover, the game doesn't show the controller controls despite choosing such at the beginning. There is also no minimap, and enemies can trigger a battle whenever you are interacting with other things.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I don't feel much excitement from [b]Saturday Morning RPG[/b], which might be happening because I'm not the intended audience. It doesn't mean that it's bad, though. It's still a nice RPG game if you don't mind the cons, although you can't expect it to be a game-changer or something. It's pretty much mediocre, which makes me in a bind about whether to recommend it or not. You can try playing the game if you think that you'll get some nostalgia, and that's if you can spare some extra money. Don't buy it at full price, though. The story isn't even finished yet.

review: This game is a lot of fun. If you're a fan of 80's pop culture you will certainly enjoy it. There's a bit of toilet humor which I'll be honest I really did not appreciate, but it's such a small gripe it doesn't even really matter. The combat is a lot of fun, and the ranking system for how well you did in battle adds a lot to the battles. I also really like the Mac Tonight reference. Mac Tonight is really cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014730910', 'num_games_owned': 1095, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1653657433}
review:
Unlike others, I did not mind the graphics. Yes, the interface is not well designed and the mix of low quality 3D coupled with 2D does not give a good effect, but you get used to it and even find it charming after a while. What I disliked most is the functionality, especially battles. 

Firstly, forget playing this with controller. Even after you set up your interface for your choice of controller, it will always show keyboard overlays for quick time events. 

There is no map, and some areas are maze-like. You have to follow directional arrows to tracked quests which often lead you to dead ends. I wouldn't have minded that if some entrances weren't too narrow. You need to switch to slow movement to accurately position your character for entrances and you need to stand right up next to the item and click it in order to pick it up/interact with it, not a pixel off.

Battles are the worst: First you have stickers, which are powerups you get per battle. You have to scratch them every single battle! Every item functions a certain way, some direct, some use a hit gauge, some use a click charge, some use quick-time events. Quick time event ones were useless to me, but that's just because I did not want to have my fingers on trigger keys at all times and the hits are not very reliable. Someone who enjoys quick time events may like them better than I did. You defend to reduce damage by clicking in time when the enemy hits you, and the action ques are not clear enough to defend reliably. You have to powerup your shot for EVERY SINGLE SHOT, otherwise your damage is pathetic even if you have your game scaled to level 1. The battling experience is so bad I had to drop the game. It feels repetitive and unnecessarily click heavy to artificially prolong the fight.

Overall, although I like the idea, it feels like the game is full of deliberate annoyances with the sole purpose of prolonging playtime.

review: It can probably entertain you for 2-3 hours and has some fun ideas to its RPG fights. There's some cute humour paired with nostalgic homage which are pretty much the main appeal of this title. If you don't feel any nostalgia for those old 80s and 90s cartoons then its probably not going to do much for you, since as a standalone experience it feels like it doesn't really hold much weight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016046767', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1614, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1640459361}
review:
A silly short RPG worth a play through or two. A funny story line, silly dialogues, wacky battles, and some well done pixel art bring this package together in a nice way. The whole Saturday morning cartoon theme is great!

It's good simple fun and treats modern gaming like a meme in an amusing way. Not a very difficult game but it's definitely worth a bit of your time if you enjoy turn based RPGs.

review: Game is bad, yall. Thinks it's clever, but it's not. UI feels half finished, and that's not even counting that it can't remember when you pick controller icons instead of keyboard icons. Combat is boring. Hope I got this trash in a bundle instead of directly paying money for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11196, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1612452129}
review:
Despite the misleading name, Saturday Morning RPG is less an RPG and more of a console style button mashing QTE game where combats are determined by smashing your keyboard exactly the right way in response to various stimuli.  But, faithful to the low quality premise, this is mobile/console crapware that's been dumped on Steam hoping to cash gouge PC gamers. 

There's a lot of things wrong with this train wreck, and the awful gameplay is just part of it.  For some reason they use ugly lazy retro pixel graphics, but only sometimes.  So not trying to emulate the pixel graphics that developers in the 1990's had to use because they had no choice, because the backgrounds are sometimes almost decently created.  Imagine setting out to make your video game look bad *and* inauthentic at the same time!

Mobile games don't belong on Steam.  Ugly pixel art is obsolete and the last refuge of the budgetless/talentless (or maybe both) indie dev.   You can buy Skyrim on sale for less than the price of this bundle worsener.  Impossible to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117049851', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 979, 'last_played': 1607233654}

author: {'steamid': '76561198075620441', 'num_games_owned': 2303, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1588652397}
review:
This game hurts both literally and figuratively. Literally because this button mashing of a game currently has my arm cramping up from spamming prompts for attacks, and figuratively because it sucks. The only thing I liked about the game was the 80's theme, and realistically I am not really a huge fan of that either. Combat is boring and repetitive, abilities all feel weak, boring, a pain to use or all of the above, the art has zero consistency, feels like it does not properly scale with resolutions higher than 1080p, and just looks ugly to me, music and sound is acceptable at best and repetitive at worst, the story is eh and feels like it has nothing more to it than 80's tropes, the characters are all one dimensional, and the mechanics are all button mashing or stick flinging and I was straight up worried about damaging my keyboard so I went to my controller and then worried about mashing my A button to hell instead. I got my steam cards and left. I felt no connection or interest to this game. 

4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197980447624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 994, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 994, 'last_played': 1587608760}

author: {'steamid': '76561198173041926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 723, 'last_played': 1648559889}
review: What I've enjoyed about this game comes in many forms. Foremost, its steeped in a Saturday Morning Cartoon style, hence the name, which transports me back to a simpler & happier time. The story has a whimsical charm, carried by delightful characters. The combat has a unique turn-based style, albeit it could be tedious to some, I rarely tire of it. All in all, this is a once of a kind game, that hopefully will inspire more like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070702969', 'num_games_owned': 271, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1322, 'last_played': 1457332024}
review:
The game was pretty decent, and I would have recommended it for fans of RPGs and the 80s, and those who remember the 80s.

However, the developer has done an awful job at supporting this game. For instance, they have repeatedly said that they would fix the broken/unachieveable achievements, but years later there is still no update to fix them. In the meantime, they have released several ports to most of the other major consoles that have less issues than the Steam version. Don't expect support from The Mighty Rabbit, they've completely abandoned their games for their other project, Limited Run Games.

UPDATE: It looks like The Mighty Rabbit has finally fixed some/all of the achievement issues after several years of being broken. Good for them for finally supporting their game. Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003320135', 'num_games_owned': 3640, 'num_reviews': 212, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1558792250}
review:
I'll be perfectly honest with you ‚Äì I gave up on Saturday Morning RPG about halfway into episode five. Before I even get into review proper and why I did something I basically never do it should be noted this is an incomplete game seeing as episode six is still missing. So that's already something going against the game, but it turns out it really didn't matter in this particular case because base product had enough problems.

At its core this is effectively a JRPG albeit one styled after Saturday morning cartoons of yore. Admittedly, not being a US resident it did not speak to me on that level specifically, but I get what it was going for. I was personally less into G.I. Joe and Transfomers, more into Conan the Adventurer and Bucky O'Hare myself. Game comes with that kinda derpy protagonist + geek friend included. So much so the entire first episode is actually a dream that sets you up for way more... or does it? Setting and episodic, literally and figuratively, approach to it is not one of the problems game suffers from. There's a HOOD commander who will totally get you next time, suspiciously familiar vehicle transforming robots who have a show-off of their own in one of the episodes, and plenty of pop culture references anyone in the know with media should recognize. For god's sake, the Wizard with his BAD glove is your spiritual guide early on.

It's mechanics and design where game fails, sadly. Episodes are mercifully relatively short which still manages to be a problem because for overwhelming majority of play time you'll be fighting couple of re-skinned enemy types. Pair it with simplistic combat system itself relying on timing defense hits to reduce damage or varying degrees of annoyance to execute attacks of your own and you have helluva time ahead of you. See, all of that isn't really a problem and other JRPGs have done it to varying degrees of success, but the real problem with Saturday Morning RPG lies in just how common place combat is. I got bored with it by the time episode two ended, and inventory management was a separate source of annoyance that reared its ugly head at about the same time. Your attacks depend on items you've found to equip and out of about three dozen I've found probably six that weren't completely annoying to use? Add to that sticker scratching you can do before combat to gain bonuses and you're looking at a prospect of tiring your thumbs out real fast.

Should you play this one? I'd advise against it unless you've tapped out all other JRPGs under the sun. If I was honest with myself I would've probably stopped way earlier, but I hoped game would improve as it went on. It does go up in scale, at least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051874509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2541, 'last_played': 1538067265}
review:
[h1]I love Saturday Morning RPG.  It's so bad.[/h1]

Remember the eighties?
Remember sitting in front of your TV on Saturday morning, soaking up the cartoon goodness?
How it was all ridiculously over-the-top and crazy, but somehow, at the end of every half an hour episode, everything worked out?

Well, if you remember those days fondly, you'll find a lot to love in Saturday Morning RPG.
The trouble is, you'll also find less fun things there, too.
Memory can be a fickle thing.

[b]So, What Is Saturday Morning RPG?[/b]

Saturday Morning RPG is a RPG game that styles itself after Saturday Morning cartoons from the 80's.  There are ridiculous monsters, crazy quests and zany characters to meet as you make your way through little episodes that chronicle the life and times of Marty - our protagonist - as he goes up against his nemesis, Captain Hood.

Everything in Saturday Morning RPG plays to it's very eighties setup:  your powers are fun things like karate moves, or pizza health replenishers.  The graphics are all mostly sprite work with some beautiful backdrops for each battle you enter into.  The music and sounds are all very inspired by the eighties.  In short, it's a RPG love letter to that time period.

As Marty, you do quests which grant experience.  As you gain experience, you go up in levels.  Upon reaching a new level, you get to choose a stat [from a random set of two] to boost.  Your vanilla move set is always available to you in the form of regular punches that build up a "power meter" of sorts.  You can spend this power meter on either more devastating attacks that you pick up from around the world in the form of toys [more on that in a moment], but you can also just unleash a more potent punch.

Your more advanced moves come from pickups in the world.  Find a bandana?  Wear it [and four other such pickups] and now you have access to a special move granted by that bandana in your "advanced moves" category.  Most of these pickups are lying out in the world, but occasionally, you'll stumble across a vending machine where you can spend money to just outright buy the move sets you want [assuming that vending machine has those items.]

Combat is also regulated through passive abilities that you find as "stickers" in the world - find a little red carton of fast food on your travels?  Open it to discover a sticker.  The red boxes are fairly plentiful, but the purple boxes are more rare and grant more interesting passives [extra money, bonus experience, that sort of thing.]

These stickers go on a binder that has a cover which can also grant you passives.

By now you will have noticed that I'm talking about the combat an awful lot, and that's because while there is questing [and while the quests are zany and fun] many of them culminate in "fight the bad guys and win."  And that's where the cracks start appearing for this particular game.

Like the power glove, Saturday Morning RPG is "so bad" in the sense that - unfortunately - instead of leaning into it's premise, it almost literally drowns in it with far too many battles for it's own good.  This problem is compounded with the way battles work:  in order to maximize your power meter, you have three ways of building it:  mashing the buttons on your controller like a maniac, a flat boost [which takes longer to charge up] or a minigame in which you attempt to hit "maximum" by timing a button press correctly.

The "rhythmic" nature of the combat is abundant everywhere:  hitting your block button at the correct time deflects damage.  Timing hits on some enemies is crucial, lest they huddle up and shrug off all your incoming damage.  Sometimes, it's even crucial that you hold off on attacking at all so that you can build up power to unleash it all in one go to one shot an enemy, in case it starts healing up the other enemies surrounding it.

And this, then, is the part of Saturday Morning RPG that's exhausting.  The game is built around it's source material and then fed through a combat grinder.  There's too much of the combat, the combat feels too repetitive and all of this works against the game's overall fun factor.

This problem is exacerbated by the achievements.  Originally intended as a 20+ episode opus, the achievements [at one time] wanted you to kill an absurd number of enemies, collect a crazy amount of coin and generally do over the top legwork for full completion.  Some of this is still present [and at the time of this review, two achievements are functionally impossible.] though it's toned down to a point where the game won't consume thousands of hours [even so, my forty+ hours that are on-record are probably "about right" for a completionist run.]

[b]Does it all hang together and should you buy it?[/b]

Sort of?  If you're a fan of the aesthetics [they're lovely] and have a fondness for the eighties and don't mind a game that's literally dripping in references like that, you'll find a lot to like, here.  But you'll also grow very wary of the battle system.

If you like turn based games, then this one's tricky to recommend.  It is turn-based, but good grief!  That guage building nonsense is for the birds.

Either way, I strongly recommend watching some gameplay and I strongly recommend buying on sale.  This game's a bit of a tough sell at the best of times and I can't - in good conscience - suggest buying it full price [especially since the developers have basically up and abandoned the game.]

[b]Pros At A Glance[/b]

[list]
[*]Great aesthetics:  Wonderful pixel art and backgrounds.
[*]Fun references:  Sure.  There's LOTS of them and that might get tiring, but if you're into this sort of thing, you'll be quite happy.
[*]Great structure:  I'd love to see more episodic RPG's like this one.
[/list]

[b]Cons At A Glance[/b]

[list]
[*]Abandoned project:  This means there are broken achievements and a plot that's never fully resolved.
[*]That battle system:  Good grief.  Too many random battles, coupled with the way the system works actively make me resent it.
[*]Overzealous achievement requirements:  This has been dialed back a little, but they're still CRAZY, given the amount of content in this game.
[/list]

I like this game.  I recommend it to eighties enthusiasts and turn based gamers.  If you're both, [i]mostly[/i] two thumbs up.  If you're into one but not the other, one thumb that is [i]mostly[/i] up and I suggest you buy this on sale.  If you're not either of those things, well...this game is probably not for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032588847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1620716444}
review:
Poorly made.

You've got 3D environments mixed with paper thin 2D characters merged in that environment.

You have parts of the dialogue that move, giving you a headache trying to read them.

You have Z X and V keys to do some of the blocking and fighting during the battles. This is stupidly mixed with mouse movements for mini-games such as scratching lottery tickets"

Don't buy this game at all, I think this game has an Identity Crisis and fails to entertain.

author: {'steamid': '76561198262626587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 373, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1646085338}
review:
What is Saturday Morning RPG ?

I thought this would have been another one of those hiddem gems I found on steam out of nowhere, it looked promising on the store page videos, it could have been pretty much a similar experience to games like paper mario and such but ON PC !, turns out it isnt, the game's artstyle is all over the place and quite ugly sometimes, the gameplay and combat overall doesnt offer many diversity in terms of how many attacks or items I can use, and it just lacks "weight" Ive seen many other indie games who went the same route do much better than this, they understood that when you do a turn-based combat you need to give it some visual show-off, some weight to compensate, this game the combat just feels limited when it comes to options and I can see this getting very boring and repetitive after some time, the story didnt feel interesting either and I lost interest after a while, a huge shame, it could have been much more but at the end of the day its just a low budget game that its better left alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993732487', 'num_games_owned': 1452, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1531444417}
review:
As a fan of both RPG's and Saturday Morning TV... old school Saturday Morning TV anyway, this felt like something that would scratch both itches at once. And it did... for a while.

Saturday Morning RPG stars Marty, a regular high school student turned hero and more pop culture references than Ready Player One. After getting powered up by a trapper keeper notebook with scratch n' sniff stickers he's ready to fight the the not quite copywrited forces of evil.

The game plays like a standard issue RPG, exploring areas, finding treasure, fighting enemies. All the stuff people would look for in an RPG. What stands this apart though is the fact that the game is episodic, like a Telltale game for example. Meaning you play through different episodes of the story that all connect together in an RPG format. This is actually a very interesting idea which I think would be good if it caught on. The battle system is nice and incorporates many different features from other RPG's to create a battle experience that is familiar but unique. The 8 bit/16 bit graphics do help keep the retro athestic going, not just as a retro game but as the throwback the game is meant to be. Finally, it's short. That's a plus for folks who don't have 100 hours to sink into an RPG. You can clear through this in about 6-7 hours.

While the game is good and clearly crafted with love, it could have done with a bit of polish overall. The absolute overabundance of pop culture references have the subilty of a sledgehammer and will bog you down by the end of episode 2 (out of 5). It causes the "Yeah, I get it." effect so often you'll be rolling your eyes constantly. Battle ends up being a cinch after leveling up a bit. Taking your time to beat up enemies you don't have to in the early episodes makes the later episodes almost trivial to do. Boss battles are no big deal either, just a normal enemy with larger health. All of the bosses actually end up summoning normal mooks to the fight as part of their normal routines, saldy robbing any actual challenge to bosses. Finally, it suffers from what all good 80's cartoon's suffered from, poorly cohesive writing. By Episode 3, and being bogged down by constant pop culture references, you start to realize that there isn't really a over arching plot so much as barely assosiated one offs. And yes that's what Saturday morning cartoons did back in the day, but at this point... we can do better.

If you're a fan of pop culture refences and RPG's that are willing to try something new or incorporate some good gameplay elements, give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198170019417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1529192514}

The combat system is pleasing, but it gets quickly repetitive. However the animations are absolutely great, and totally fit the geeky atmosphere of the game.
I did not like the humor of the game, but I am not fully fluent in English. It is very parodic, filled with clich√© and references to pop-culture.
Not my jam, but still a nice game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061026720', 'num_games_owned': 1986, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1529589037}
review:
Saturday morning RPG is, unsurprisingly, an rpg set in a saturday morning cartoon world. If you ever thought about how boring it'd be to be in a saturday morning cartoon world, you can probably stop reading this review now. 

For those of you still reading, let me get deeper into why this game isn't fun. First of all, this game is absolutely nothing but combat. There's some questing, but it either leads to nothing, or it leads to more combat. As such, this game will live or die on it's combat. Unfortunately, a few decisions in how combat works makes it flawed to the point of being broken. So let me detail these

1) You regain all health and resources at the end of combat
2) your attacks(the ones that actually matter) are limited in use
3) You can "charge up" dragonball Z style by essentially standing there like a moron and screaming
4) Basically all attacks require a minigame

These 4 facts make combat completely fucking boring. Due to 2 you have to get the most out of every attack, so you use fact 3 and charge up to 9x to get the most out of every attack, and then use one of your limited attacks to defeat an enemy. All of this requiring a minigame, remember. You stand there, charging up repeatedly so that your attacks more or less instant hit. And then at the end, you regain all health, and then start over on another combat. Even if you removed fact 4, this still wouldn't be fun, but it'd be at least less  annoying. Playing optimally is incredibly fucking boring. 

Oh, enemies can also apply speed debuffs(which give you less turns compared to them) and accuracy debuffs(so that your attacks miss enemies more often) so fuck the game on that basis alone

author: {'steamid': '76561198307615811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1550384440}
review:
Best played in moderation.

The stickers will make you rage if you try to do this game in one go. Every fight you have to mash left and right arrow keys to get buffs that will help you win fights. I've played midway in the second episode. The power ups are cool and the effects they do on attack are awesome. 
If I wasn't a fan of pixel art and retro game styles and rpg's with a bit of comedy then I doubt this game would appeal to me. If you get the comedic refrences and love the art and rpgs then don't pass this up. 
Remember; moderation. 

Video of my gameplay from episode 2:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kWM6hAo5N1Q

author: {'steamid': '76561198016156714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1511464374}
review: The more I heard about Saturday Morning RPG, the more I was intrigued. It was a sleeper hit sort of RPG, themed after the classic cartoons and culture of the 80's, and was one of the few games handpicked by startup Limited Run Games for a physical release. Instead of shoving the existence of 80's culture in your face, Saturday Morning RPG seemed to bathe and flourish in it. There‚Äôs even one point a character that hints to the classic early 90‚Äôs flick, The Wizard. Yet, Saturday Morning RPG puts so much respect to what it wants to praise, that it forgets to leave anything for itself.A nice time waster but in itself not as good as Pacman or Atari

author: {'steamid': '76561198019576097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 322, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1510800742}
review:
Warning: In case of doubt, don't buy this game.

- History makes no sense.
- Combat is tedious and repetitive (scratching the sticks before every single battle sucks).
- The only good music is the one from the trailer.

So, why I recommend it? For some reason I kept playing till the end and had 2 or 3 good laughs, mainly due nostalgia and 80/90's references, I think the fact that it's episodic helped too. 

To sum up, buy it to fulfill your nostalgia if you got some spare change, younger players might hate everything here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172051855', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1527148695}
review: God this game hit the nastalga bone just right. I may of been raised in the 90's but I get 97% of the jokes and refrenses cause me and my mom would always watch old chesse 80's and 90's movies and old 80's cartoons like HE-Man and Ducktails/Darkwing Duck when ever she had free time. It's a solid RPG with a turn based/Quick time battle system. My only gripe with this game is the broke controler bindings and that if you read between the lines the dev's said they really no longer give a shit about this game cause it sold poorly so chapter six will most likely never come out. Other than that it's a great game and nastalga trip. 8.3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197990725997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 360, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1508378473}
review: This was totally up my alley back when at the pique of the surge of indie gamers that arrived on steam. I recommend it to those that are fans of parody, comedy, nostalgia, unique games that really serve no purpose other than to entertain you at a superficial level. There is no insightful content. There is no motivation to move forward other than to see more jokes. Play through it once nad that's it. Great for the price, I am sure you can get it super cheap somewhere like a bundle site, but well worth it if you enjoy[ed] these games!

author: {'steamid': '76561197977283789', 'num_games_owned': 622, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1523125551}
review:
Tons of encounters and an extremely easy-yet-tedious battle system makes this really tough to enjoy. Prepare to spend most of your time waiting around blocking enemy attacks, trying to squeeze in the one turn you get for every 3 of theirs - only to miss, because they've been spamming accuracy debuffs the whole time.

I can only guess this was an attempt to make the game longer, but it's probably the worst way to do so.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972040704', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 725, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1404557543}
review: Nostalgia has never really been a thing for me. However, i made the mistake when I watched the trailer for Saturday Morning RPG, of assuming that I could somehow [i]buy[/i] a sense of nostalgia for myself. Newsflash: it didn't work. I soon discovered that no matter how many 1980s things they cram into the game, the many references and corny jokes wrapped around a so-so video game just weren't going to cut it. Saturday Morning RPG banks too hard on nostalgia without having much else of substance, and I cannot recommend the game for that reason.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198122163777', 'num_games_owned': 1846, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1499302649}
review:
This game is recommended for those of you who enjoyed the 80's.  

It's a great farce of many cliches of the 80's right down to the scratch-and-sniff stickers on your Trapper-Keeper.  If you want to poke fun at bad story plots, dated technology, and rad conversations then you will probably get a laugh out of this title.  It's not deep and the gameplay is actually pretty repetitive, but good gameplay was never really the point of this game.  It's a trip down nostalgia lane and little more.

Those of you who are too young to remember the 80's (or prefer not to) should probably stear clear as the actual meat of the gameplay isn't really all that fun.  If you don't get the jokes, this title will have little else to offer you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960830998', 'num_games_owned': 926, 'num_reviews': 264, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1526174200}
review:
As a UK player who lived through the 80's as a child - nothing in this game induces any kind of nostalgia. I'm not getting any of the "Saturday Morning TV" vibe at all - no Double Dare , Philip Schofield and that bloody gopher, Cheggers or anything.

A fairly generic RPG with elements taken from paper mario type combat and sticker collections.

Overall, for a brit, I rate this as something I'd like to see in the "Gunk Pit".

If its on sale, you are American and paper mario style endless combat is your thing - it's probably going to be worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993825371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1495968605}
review:
Leider kein gutes Spiel auch wenn die Saturday Morning Thematik an sich gut umgesetzt wurde und das Game so sicher ein gewisses Notalgiegef√ºhl in so manchem Gamer ausl√∂sen wird.
Die Story ist dementsprechend sehr trashig und sicher einer der "gro√üen" Pluspunkte des Spiels.
Der h√§sslichen Grafik kann ich dagegen wenig abgewinnen, grad au√üerhalb der K√§mpfe einfach ein h√§ssliches 2D/3D Gemisch.
Die rundenbasiertenK√§mpfe selbst fand ich auch recht √∂de. Anfangs fand ich den etwas ungew√∂hnlichen Ansatz dieser interessant aber es wird recht schnell klar dass diese ziemlich einfach sind. 
Zudem empfinde ich das System die Angriffe zu verst√§rken (was essentziell wichtig ist) als √ºberfl√ºssig an, in meinen Augen verl√§ngert das die K√§mpfe nur. Zudem gibt es starke Angriffe die zu sehr vereinfachen und dann wieder nutzlose Angriffe die es selten lohnt sie auszuf√ºhren.

Ein Spiel mit guten und schlechten Facetten, in meinen Augen √ºberwiesen die negativen.
Wenn das Spiel im Sale ist k√∂nnen es sich gro√üe Fans von Saturday Morning Cartoons aber ruhig mal anschauen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026089591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1495247248}
review:
I hate to give it a bad review, but the combat system is just awful.  So far there are like 4 attacks done over and over and over and over and over again.  The nostalga factor is great.  The animation is a beautfil mix of regular and pixel and the controls handle well.  

However, the programmers were SO SLOPPY that they use the keyboard control icons even if you use a controler so you can't figure out what button corresponds to what effectively removing one of the attack options.  The rest is wiggle the mouse, time the button tap, repeat until you just with it was over.  Don't worry though, the episodes are so short it will be soon.  For dirt cheap it's OK, but there's a decent chance you'll just give up regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975678852', 'num_games_owned': 2156, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1495052389}
review:
Not a bad little love letter to the 80s. 

Basically an RPG split into 5 different "episodes". Gameplay loop is explore, collect stickers to buff you and items to use in battle, get fetch quests from NPCs around the map while battling bad guys, fight an end boss in a dungeon... then onto the next episode. 

Your stats and items carry between episodes. There's also arena and endless modes if you really enjoy the battle system. 

It's a bid tedious by the last episode, but in all it's pretty fun,

review:
Got it on sale for $0.99 if I remember right, and it doesn't feel like even that price was worth it.

The Battle system is so overflowing with minigames and button mashing that after 30 minutes of play my arm hurts, literally.

I'd love to play through the game for the huge nostalgia hit, but the Battle system is so horrible that I've completely lost interest.  If I had played it enought right after buying to realize this, I would have gotten my money back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131816676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1491735710}
review:
Recensione: Saturday Morning RPG

RPG vecchio stile ispirato ai cartoni americani del sabato mattina. Non molto divertente.

Sicuramente le citazioni sono moltissime, cos√¨ come gli easter egg e simili, ma il sistema di combattimento risulta noioso fin dai primi minuti di gioco. Certo potere usare oggetti comuni di ogni giorno come armi aiuta, ma ben presto useremo sempre lo stesso set di oggetti che √® efficace contro qualunque nemico.

La trama √® una delle pi√π anonime che possa esistere quasi senza colpi di scena e sorprese, il nostro eroe Marty deve sconfiggere in ogni episodio il super-cattivo che minaccia la citt√†, fine.
Sembra una delle "fiabe brevi che finiscono malissimo", solo che alla fine finisce bene.

Non mi √® piaciuto, magari perch√© non ho colto tutti i riferimenti ai vari programmi televisivi e cartoni, oppure perch√© n√© la trama, n√© il sistema di combattimento sono interessanti o divertenti.

Saturday morning RPG √® stato pi√π una perdita di tempo che altro. 

4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198026852317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 679, 'last_played': 1558827086}
review: Let me start with the only thing I don't like about this game-The stickers. Having to scratch off stickers for every fight brings back awful memories of the first Mario Party. Other than that one gripe, I have nothing but good things to say. A Paper Mario style twitch reaction RPG combat system that gives you the option to charge any attack makes battles engaging more than just selecting attack over and over. Numerous "spells" to equip give you the chance to experiment and find what you like. Loads of 80's pop culture references are supported by catchy synth music and great pixel animation. Only 5 chapters is a bit of a bummer and the game may be slightly overpriced for its' length but arena mode, endless mode, and that tantalizing %100 completion give you a decent bang for your buck. I hope to see a sequel. A sequel with no stickers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980160718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1484481548}
review:
I purchased this on sale, but it is worth the $7. 

I have had a soft spot for JRPGs for a long time, but they often take themselves very seriously, are very stereotypical, and have repetitive (very long) gameplay. Sometimes this is just what I want, and sometimes I want Saturday Morning RPG (SMRPG).

Divided into short episodes, this game is all about charm and style. It is an indie production, and the amount of care he has put into the writing is apparent. The graphics try for pixel-love, and mostly succeed, but the 3d areas lack definition. No, this isn't so much about the look, but about the ideas. 

It's about having fun. It doesn't take itself seriously, it doesn't last too long, it doesn't boast complex systems. It's a Saturday Morning cartoon, and it is filled with charm and nostalgia.

Enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999034258', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1482471336}
review:
SMRPG feels broken and patchy. 

I can't recommend it, the on screen elements are very abrasive and the movement is finicky. The UI is awful - won't stay set to gamepad controls displayed, so I constantly had no idea which button to press. The 'folder' is difficult to navigate and the game elements (attacks, boosts, etc) are never really explained, which left me just equipping and buying and spamming things all over the place. The stats are not explained or really referenced anywhere so I was left applying miscellaneous boosts that might have had an impact. With a couple of improvements or indeed an overhaul of the menu/folder system and a bit more indication for what to use, the game might be playable, but it would need many more changes for me to recommend it.

review: Granted I only paid $0.49 for it, so I don't have much to complain and for what it is it's an alright game. The UI is really frustrating, especially if you're playing on pad because I kept trying to change the button style layout and it keeps defaulting to the keyboard style layout. And as a personal opinion, I'm not too fond of the visuals, there's more 3D elements than 2D elements and it's a bit of a mess. Honestly, if you want a game that's very 1980s esque but filled with easter eggs, go play Retro City Rampage instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961161953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1296, 'last_played': 1480301573}
review: If you are a child of the 80s and 90s, and you enjoy nostalga, then you owe it to yourself to play this game.  This is your childhood crammed into one game!  If you're not a child of the 90s and 80s, then you need a pop culture care package to get all of the references in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102907529', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1548621084}
review:
Silly bit of nostalgic fun for less than a buck (it was 90 cents when I bought it). I used to play this on my iPad, but it became unsupported and sound stopped working so I gave up on it. Nice to have it back on PC. If you grew up in the 70's, 80's or maybe even the early 90's this game just might make you smile.

ONE PROBLEM THOUGH: the button prompts keep getting switched on me. For example, if I play using an Xbox controller, it shows me keyboard key prompts sometimes, and ruins my ability to react. I know this is a cheap little budget game, so I don't really expect much support, but it would be really nice to see that bug fixed in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048799891', 'num_games_owned': 7625, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1476717961}
review:
First thing the game does is ask you what kind of button prompts you want: keyboard, PlayStation or Xbox.

Second thing the game does is fail at showing you the prompt you selected and it just shows you the keyboard prompts.

The third thing I noticed was that this game was written by an autistic 5 year old and that the references are completely inane and boring. Great, the main character is named after Marty McFly. Original. Oh, The Wizard showed up! He said "so bad" like the Power Glove scene! I grew up in the 80s and corporations aren't "ruining our childhood" by releasing remakes, you people are doing it by not ever shutting the fuck up about Back to the Future and the NES. Reference something fresh for once!

Fourth thing I noticed is how dreadfully ugly everything but the pixel art (which is only for characters) is. Everything else looks like a rudimentary polygon game from 1984.

Nah, I think I hate this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049226389', 'num_games_owned': 1703, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1474095831}
review:
The story is as generic as they come, there is the occasional genuinely funny quip, but besides that, it is nothing special.

The battles are ridiculously repetitive and the control scheme makes it a chore. 

Despite my best efforts, and selecting so in the options menu, the on screen prompts would not show for my Xbox 360 controller so any quick time events were met with me trying to figure out what Z, X, Y, V were on a controller. Not a fun time and just adds to the frustration.

The visuals were great, I enjoyed the low-res 2D sprites in a 3Dish world, it game the game a nice look but the game is a complete letdown for me on a technical level, so much so that I have had to give up on the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044114790', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1515327662}
review: Saturday Morning RPG. Um RPG que lembra as gloriosos sabados de manh√£ e com cada golpe com uma mecanica difenrente.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969333093', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1472956141}
review:
A well-written RPG that pays hilarious homage to many iconic figures of the 80's. If you're familiar with G.I. Joe, Transformers, Care Bears, Back to the Future, Michael Jackson, Top Gun, or Jean Claude Van Damme, you will find many chuckles to be had throughout the course of the game.

You play as Marty, and the game is played through 5 episodes, each introducing unique locations and characters to the overall plot. Gameplay itself mostly consists of the standard RPG elements: Explore, level up, complete quests, and advance the storyline. Your party will always be a one-person affair, but this is acceptable due to the customization options available to Marty. 

You will find stickers, 5 of which can be scratched prior to each battle to give Marty bonuses (or debuffs for enemies). In addition to this, there is a pretty big selection of items that Marty may also equip. Each of these items is an attack that Marty can perform in battle, and each item ranges in damage, speed, accuracy, and uses per battle. Many of these items also have unique QTEs that give the fighting a bit of flavor as well. Add this with a charging system that is required to make your attacks more lethal, and a timing system that puts emphasis on speed as well, and there's actually a little strategy required in some of the fights.

The music is also pretty good. It probably won't make many Top 10 lists, but it is quite fitting for the gameplay. I wish they would've gave the music more of an 80's hair-band vibe, but I was satisfied with the overall score.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025135104', 'num_games_owned': 3459, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1468729964}
review:
* Ten√≠a esperanzas con este juego. Promet√≠a abundantes referencias a mi ni√±ez de caricaturas y pel√≠culas: Volver al futuro, G.I. Joe, He-Man, Michael Jackson, Space Jam, etc√©tera. Pues s√≠ cumple, s√≠ tiene estas cosas. Y est√°n bien trabajadas, bien‚Ä¶ puestas, una junto a otra, en procesi√≥n, en la misma caja. ¬øEntonces por qu√©‚Ä¶? Y luego sigue la historia. Te dan un cuaderno m√°gico, ¬°radical!, y este cuaderno m√°gico tiene pegatinas (stickers, pues) y portadas ¬°radicales! que cambian tus habilidades y atributos. ¬øY por qu√© diablos me siento tan dudoso con este juego? 

* Quiz√°s, este es el primer RPG que juego en la vida donde s√≥lo manejas a un personaje. Jugu√© dos episodios y no hubo se√±al de alg√∫n compa√±ero, alg√∫n otro personaje con cual identificarme, o relacionarme, o quejarme. Mi √∫nica esperanza era seguir utilizando a este reflejo retorcido de Marty McFly (el personaje principal) y crear una especie de‚Ä¶ compenetraci√≥n. En dos cap√≠tulos no sucedi√≥. 

* La historia, por supuesto, desde el principio, promet√≠a ser absurda. No esperaba otra cosa, pero‚Ä¶ bueno, quiz√°s este es un claro ejemplo de porqu√© meter un bonche de referencias no es suficiente para alimentar una historia. Sobre todo un RPG epis√≥dico, escrito por diferentes personas. Y un RPG vive y se disfruta mucho m√°s, al menos, gracias a una historia convencional y estructurada. Si no est√°n buscando una historia, tal vez puedan disfrutar este juego y sus referencias constantes a las caricaturas del s√°bado por la ma√±ana (en el gringo, claro, lo que nosotros los mexicanos ve√≠amos entre semana, despu√©s de la escuela). 

* En cuanto a la jugabilidad: El juego es una perra dif√≠cil. Ganar una batalla puede considerarse un verdadero triunfo. Prep√°rate para que te duelan los dedos y cambiar de controles porque vas a estar button mashing y meneando las palancas como si no hubiera ma√±ana. Y claro, como s√≥lo usas a un personaje, algunas veces te vas a sentir m√°s solo que nunca, y totalmente en desventaja, cuando debas enfrentarte a tres soldados cobra, un sniper y un hombre lagartija. 

* La pregunta dif√≠cil: ¬øRecomiendo este juego? No lo s√©. Obviamente los desarrolladores trabajaron muy duro y, supongo, en otras circunstancias este juego me hubiera entusiasmado mucho. Lo intent√© dos veces, durante dos cap√≠tulos, y simplemente me repele. ¬øSer√° la dificultad? El dise√±o del juego no es malo, es una obvia referencia, y m√°s referencias, todo es una referencia. Y eso est√° bien, pero‚Ä¶ ¬øpor qu√©? ¬øPor qu√© no aprovechar el gran talento que tiene el equipo para hacer algo original, arriesgarse un poco, dejar de pitorrearse o de ba√±arse en nostalgia? ¬øPor qu√© no hacer algo nuevo? Ah, no lo s√©. Ser√© sincero: no recomiendo este juego para todos. Supongo que requiere a un estilo de jugador muy especial y yo no entro en el target. 

Hice un breve let's play por ac√°: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vnam3zDRABk&list=PLf3hSHJ6VZaNnIDKIR7DEmsPhqB4Dlp-M

author: {'steamid': '76561197971915229', 'num_games_owned': 966, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1467662970}
review:
I get what the creators are trying to do with this game, and I respect that. The first two episodes are the best part of the work, with some clever design and interesting ideas.

Sadly, the remainder of the game starts falling flat and doesn't really recover. The fifth episode is unfortunately both obtuse in the puzzles presented and pretty short, and the story they laid out just kind of takes a sharp left turn into "wut" territory.

The nostalgia factor is pretty strong, but the humor is a bit overly pun-dependent for my tastes. I picked it up on Steam sale, and I'd recommend giving it a shot in a sale if you have nostalgia for 80's pop culture, but other than that I can't really recommend this one.

A final note: if you have motor disabilities, steer clear of the game completely. A lot of the combat is based around either timed presses or button mashing/control stick shaking, and if you have trouble with fine motor movements, you will likely have a much harder time with this game. I did not see an accessibility option for getting around that requirement.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066458761', 'num_games_owned': 933, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1467143706}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG is a very fun and entertaining little game with smirk-worthy writing, an interesting combat system, and a great sense of style. So why is it not recommended? Because the control prompts are broken.

When you start a new game, it asks you to select your button prompt style; keyboard, Xbox 360, or Playstation. Unfortunately, for some users, myself inclued, this option simply doesn't work. I've selected 360 prompts and applied the change multiple times, and still the game is showing me keyboard inputs. Looking at the forums, it seems other people have been having this problem and have been asking for a fix since the game launched, over 2 years ago. That's 2 years during which the developers have completely ignored complaints about a broken option which significantly hurts the experience for many players. Knowing this, I cannot in good conscience recommend the game to new players. Mighty Rabbit need to fix this problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005307805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1635738766}
review:
This is a really fun, lovingly crafted RPG. I delayed buying it because I was afraid it would botch the mid-80s setting or turn out to be an unimaginative parody. That was a mistake. This game is a genuinely creative love-song to the era. The NPC's have personalities, the setting and art is delightful, and the music is perfect. One quibble is that the soundtrack could have been longer. The combat system could be deeper, but it's adequate to make the battles exciting and often challenging.

I was particularly impressed with the writing. The authors managed to combine some of the best storytelling elements of early RPG's with mid-1980s' cartoon serials. Like it's inspirations, the game's stories are funny yet also morally sincere. The snarky irony of 1990-current storytelling is conspicuous by its absence.

Highly recommended. It's not necessary at all to have lived through the mid-1980s to enjoy this game. I hope to see more from this game's developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036654880', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1452407285}

author: {'steamid': '76561197984219654', 'num_games_owned': 775, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1599499244}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG √© um game que demanda que voc√™ tenha sido crian√ßa/adolescente entre os anos 80 e inicio de 90. Apelando forte para a nostalgia do jogador atrav√©s de refer√™ncias de jogos, filmes, desenhos animados e m√∫sicas. "Saturday Morning RPG" consegue divertir com um humor leve.

+ Nostalgia pra tudo que √© lado.
+ Utiliza uma forma n√£o convencional de batalhas por turnos.
- Com o tempo, os confrontos parecem mais uma obriga√ß√£o do que entretenimento. 

O grande problema √© que o combate em turnos com defesa e ataque interativos (Aperte A no momento correto pra defender) aos poucos vai ficando ma√ßante por voc√™ ter tantos duelos no decorrer dos 5 epis√≥dios. A hist√≥ria principal n√£o aparece andar t√£o bem quanto as ref√™rencias feitas, e acaba sendo esquec√≠vel.
Basicamente, se voc√™ queria um jogo com 'humor' parecido com "Apenas um Show/Regular Show", esse √© o game. Agora, se voc√™ nasceu de 96 em diante, talvez n√£o consiga pescar muitas das piadas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025291625', 'num_games_owned': 521, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1453685976}
review:
On occasion I find myself in a "gaming slump" - Thankfully, Saturday Morning RPG was there to pull me from my distressed state and make me feel like a kid again. 

Everything I loved about growing up in the 80s is there in one subtle reference or another.

The only thing disheartening about this game is that there aren't more episodes. :`(

author: {'steamid': '76561197969425957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1454490443}
review:
A decent RPG that has a nice old school saturday morning feel to it (duh). I love the references, but younger kids probably won't get some of them; that's okay.

Some issues I have with it though:

1. The art styles don't match; you have a 3D world with clearly 2D pixelated characters, and the two don't mix well. Almost need to go high resolution 2D art to work well here.

2. Having to waggle the thumb stick every fight gets annoying very quickly. Just let those stats be static and always on so we don't have to do this.

3. Sneak attacks don't give any actual sneak bonus; even if you get one, the enemy is likely to attack first.

I'm going to spend some more time with it, but early on it feels good as an RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044298876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1435399696}

author: {'steamid': '76561198017885673', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 777, 'last_played': 1458870613}
review: A reference heavy Super Mario RPG inspired 80s/90s Cartoons Nostalgia-Gasm . If that made you cringe this isn't the game for you. May I suggest The Witcher 3?

author: {'steamid': '76561198047746934', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1532468196}
review:
Are you interested in a game that plays and feels like a real love letter to not just 80s cartoons but essentially all of 80s pop culture, from Skeletor to Back to the Future to every high school movie, written by and for children of that era?  If so, then this game is for you.  If not, then you are sad and I have no desire to speak to you further.

The music by Vince DiCola is worth the price of admission by itself--it felt like a lost happy chapter of Transformers the Movie.  The gameplay is simple and a little repetitive but like the tropes and plotlines of all our favorite memories it runs its course before it wears out its welcome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027483587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1509922876}
review:
This is a really fun old-school style turn-based RPG with a late 80s/early 90s vibe - full of nostalgia moments to SO many things, from Trapper Keepers to sewer surfing. The battles are incredibly easy and there tend to be a lot of them in a row, but that's typical of the genre. A VERY fun game, definitely worth picking up on sale, or if you're into the genre/time period- full price is reasonable. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Se9SpWYG5Eo

author: {'steamid': '76561198068234633', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1452859204}
review:
Please, release DLC's!! It's kinda pointless continue playing to reach level 50 when we only have 4 episodes (not considering Endless and Battle mode, because of the repetition too).

But the thing is : I LOVE THIS GAME. And I feel thrilled by its achievements. But not as much as I could, since I fear it may start to get boring after a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022104383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1602275362}
review:
I am a big fan of RPG games, but even a bigger fan of Parodies. This has a very nice mix of both.

Saturday Moring RPG is the ideal RG for people who are classic gamers as well as classic cartoon lovers from the 1980's to 1990's. The game features well over 100 pop culture items, enemies, comments, even the famous enemy one liners we all know and love since comic books.

Such things that are featured are as follows...

Basket ball = Labeled as (This ball is on fire), which is a reference to the arcade game called NBA JAM
Marty = A character reference to the movie "Back To The Future"
Hover Board = A reference to the movie "Back To The Future II"

and many more that I will let you find out on your own.

The RPG Game is almost played like Super Mario RPG for SNES, and also a cross from Undertale. Many of the RPG concepts are in this game, so many RPG fans will get a kick out of this RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132624773', 'num_games_owned': 56, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1452914749}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032077970', 'num_games_owned': 670, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1014, 'last_played': 1647052813}
review:
It's on sale for $0.97 and you haven't bought it yet? Hello, anybody home? Think, McFly!

If you got that reference and you grew up with these graphics then this is your game. I even recommend it at full price. Just take a look at the names of the achievements, the developers get 80's culture in the very best way.

Now power up with a scratch n sniff sticker, paralyze that Badbot with a moonwalk and wang his buddy on the head with your keytar!

author: {'steamid': '76561198258819466', 'num_games_owned': 556, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1518317315}
review:
This is the nostalgic trip down satirical memory lane you need to feel like a kid again. Funny, chocked full of references, and with a story set up as corny and unique as old Saturday morning cartoons you will be entertained for hours. Granted, there are only four episodes right now so you won't be playing real long. However, it looks like the developers might be slowly making more. Overall, if you love RPGs, you'll want this in your collection. It's a definite win.

Pros: Wonderful writting, well developed turn based gameplay, more than just the main story to play, great soundtrack

Cons: not a lot of episodes right now (i assume more are on the way), (if you're using the keyboard) the z,x,c,v buttons are your action buttons for battle at times and you may accidentally hit other buttons (this sceme cannot be changed)

neutral note: It may benifit you if you have a knowledge of 80's pop culture. Not really needed but I feel it may help you get the jokes better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999747491', 'num_games_owned': 1568, 'num_reviews': 449, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 904, 'last_played': 1455057083}
review:
Das ist mein zweites Review f√ºr dieses Spiel. Mein urspr√ºnglich negatives Urteil hat sich inzwischen zu einem positiven gewandelt. Doch warum war mein Review zuerst negativ?
Zuerst fand ich das Spiel ganz ok, aber dann wurde es schnell recht frustrierend, da in den K√§mpfen das Gl√ºck eine viel zu grosse Rolle zu spielen schien. Nachdem ich schon frustriert aufgegeben hatte und eben mein schlechtes Review geschrieben habe, stutzte ich ob all der positiven Wertungen. War ich einfach zu bl√∂d?
Jein. Ich hatte tats√§chlich einen fatalen Fehler gemacht, denn mir war nicht bewusst, dass ich durch Tastendruck Angriffe abwehren kann. Das fand ich aber nur mittels m√ºhsamster Recherche heraus. Das Spiel sagt einem das einmal am Anfang schnell. Wenn man das wie ich irgendwie verpasst, hat man keine Chance es zu merken.
Und damit bin ich beim gr√∂ssten Manko: Die Dokumentation. Das Spiel hat keine Anleitung, es gibt im Internet keine guten Guides und man muss sich seine Infos m√ºhsam aus Steamforumseintr√§gen,d er Entwicklerhomepage und einer seehr sp√§rlichen Wiki zusammentragen. Das ist ganz klar ungen√ºgend!
Wenn man das √ºberwunden hat, dann macht das Spiel aber ordentlich Spass. Ich habe vermutlich nicht einmal die H√§lfte aller Anspielungen verstanden. Trotzdem waren diejenigen, die ich verstanden habe witzig bis sehr lustig. Die Stories sind ok, nichts weltbewegendes aber ebenfalls gut unterhaltsam.
Die Optik des Spieles gef√§llt mir trotz Pixellook. Ich finde ihn sehr stimmig. Die Steuerung ist ok, aber gerade beim navigieren im Notizbuch war ich sehr froh um meine Maus.
Ein klares Highlight des Spiels sind die vielen z.T. schr√§gen Gegenst√§nde, die dann alle als Waffen in den K√§mpfen dienen. Das macht sehr Laune, allerdings mit zwei abers: Auch hier fehlt die Dokumentation oder das Feedback des Spiels um die "Waffen" wirklich zu verstehen. Was bringt nun wie viel und warum und so weiter. Vieles ist ausprobieren, aber nicht im guten Sinne. Dazu kommt, dass die K√§mpfe recht wiederholend werden und v.a. das "Sticker kratzen" vor einem Kampf fand ich nahc k√ºrzester Zeit nur noch obernervig.

Fazit: Wer gerne humorvolle Nostalgie erlebt und Spass an Anspielungen auf Back-to-the-Future, Jean-Claude van Damme, Gl√ºcksb√§rchis und vielen mehr hat, der wird bei diesem Spiel gut bis sehr gut unterhalten und wird die einigen Macken auch gut √ºbersehen k√∂nnen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972323037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1454785358}
review: A fun if short romp through 80s Toon Tropes with some pleasing inside jokes. Combat is simple but with enough flare to keep it from becoming too rinse and repeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067460853', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1519013509}
review:
Do you like 80s nostalgia about Saturday Morning Cartoons?
Do you think most video games are too serious, lack a sense of humor and put realism above fun?
Do you want a fun indie game that you can laugh at and with at the same time?

If you answered yes to these questiones than Saturday Morning RPG is the game for you!

Saturday Morning RPG is that goofy RPG we all want but any big company would laugh right out of the meeting room.

You play as Marty who is an ordinary high school student, but in his dreams he becomes a superhero by way of a magical notebook that turns ordinary items into superpowered weapons.   He then gets to fight enemies right out of the cliche world of Saturday Morning cartoons!  

Crafted with wit and humor the world of Saturday Morning RPG is a silly break from the modern styled realistic video game you are used to.

If you don't like games that lack realistic cutting edge graphics, excessive guns, and overpriced DLC, well than this game isn't for you. 

Of course, if you want something different, exciting and fun, well then this game has it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103052532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1450640082}
