author: {'steamid': '76561198009316076', 'num_games_owned': 839, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1476340820}
review:
I find it a shame and astonishing that a game as good as Saturday Morning RPG has not done better commercially. The game has some crazy achievements, such as fighitng 1,000 and even up to 5,000 battles, based on an initial idea of 20 episodes. Since it didn't do well, they had to limit their ambitions to six episodes, hopefully with a fine tuning of the achievements in the future. 

But why is all this necessary? The game has everyone a gamer would be looking for. A series of episodes with a simple story, with tons of nostalgic references for one thing. I mean the main character is a guy named Marty, who rides a hoverboard, and gets his powers from a mysterious man known as The Wizard. The retro graphics are a joy to behold, the music is killer, and the gameplay is a very solid Paper Mario/Super Mario RPG type of thing, with button presses for better defense and better attacks. 

Not to mention your magic spells use everyday objects, from cookies and paper airplanes, to swords and baseball bats, up to toy aircraft carriers and transformer-like figurines. Hell even your notebook plays a part in the game as depending on the cover and the stickers you can enact various bonuses before each battle.

As it stands at this time there are four episodes, with total time of about 10 hours to get through all of them. There is an arena mode against two semi-tough bosses, and endless battle challenges based around each chapter. You can get the grindy achievements I mentioned earlier legitimately, but my first run through the game got me less then even 100 battles, not counting everything else. Still if you want to, the game is a pleasure to play, and with the huge episode 5 coming early next year, there's no time like the present to get in and get ready for it. 

Super totally awesomely retro-nostalgia recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018466482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1448467950}
review: Interesting humor. Lackluster graphics, gameplay or RPG appeal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010427390', 'num_games_owned': 720, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1422948290}
review:
It's really the perfect mix of light hearted 80s nostalgia and old-school unforgiving gameplay. Everything's here: energetic synth-rock (by no less than Vince DiCola), catch-all stereotypes, paper-thin storylines and ... where's the manual? Genre fans should pick it up, otherwise there are plenty of alternatives.

Fun:
- Soundtrack
- Variety of abilities
- Exploration
- Episodic Play

Not Fun:
- Battles are unforgiving, but continues are unlimited...
- Waaay too short
- Just five episodes
- No multiplayer option

Worth full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117861731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1447300441}
review:
I got everything I expected and more. Saturday Morning RPG has a sort of Paper Mario or The Stick of Truth feel because the combat system is turn based with a lot of interaction and quicktime events. The game's response is very good, so the fights always feel like you're doing what you intend to. 

The visuals are nostalgically pixelated, so if you like that kind of graphic you'll enjoy the look of this game. The music is incredible, that's probably my favourite part of this game. Every song and theme is composed very well in addition to the audio quality being fantastic.

The story has a very "Saturday morning TV show" feel to it, which makes sense considering the title of this game. I enjoyed it for the most part, especially all the references to other videos games, movies, and TV shows, but some of the dialogue gets a bit full of itself sometimes. Some NPCs will tell you their stories if you give them a chance, but that just adds a wholeness to the game in some regards.

If the developers make any DLC for this game, like new episodes, I would definitely play them. I had a lot of fun with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013723081', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 368, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1444690068}
review:
Hello,

Today i will review the game SATURDAY MORNING RPG. This game is directly influenced by the 1980's, when saturdays were fun to watch tv cartoons, and mixed up with rpg elements. There are alot of cameos also in the game including, Care Bears, Transformers, GI JOE, Fraggle Rock, and many others that i cannot even mention because it would take almost all my review to do so.

As for the game itself, it plays much like a rpg where you need to fight monsters to grind levels, find items to use on certain places, and retrieve things to use and give to others. Basically, everything you expect in a rpg. The game also does not take itself serious. It is quite campy and silly. There are alot of small things in the game that may make you laugh or those moments when you go "oooohhhh".

It seems for the most part, it works on windows 10. There is other problems though. According to the forum, the game is dead. The developer no longer works on it anymore, and the pc version is missing a episode that the nintendo switch version has. This means the developer has abadon this version and moved on. Someone suggested they may come back, but we will see. There are also broken achievements.

With the above issue of no more content and the developer seems to abadoned this game, which is quite sad, i cannot no longer recommend this game until the developer decided to actually FINISH the game. The game as it is now is unfinished. When the developer decides to actually finish the game on pc, i will change my review back to positive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027829075', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1509413989}
review: This game is just fun, as the title says just your standard chill Saturday morning rpg. Quick game, but I find the replay value to be pretty high

author: {'steamid': '76561198180512317', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1443975434}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG;

It is an episodic RPG game with Final Fantasy styled encounters. Quite possibly one of the most fun little games I've ever picked up off the Steam store. The episodes are around 30 minutes long. Just around the length of a Saturday morning cartoon. The combat system is easy to get used to and works well with an Xbox controller. Tons of fhidden items in the game that you should find but don't worry, if you don't find something on your first playthrough you can return to the episode and play it through again and find what you missed. Definitely recommend buying this game if you come across it while it's on sale. 

Pros:
- Short Episodes
- Fun Combat
- Great Story Writing/Jokes
- Replayable

Cons:
- Could Have Had Some Voice Acting

Final Verdict;

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197977663216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1443723493}
review:
Only buy this game if you're prepared to do a crapload of grinding.  The PC is VERY underpowered and will struggle to defeat even low-grade mooks until you've jacked up his stats.  Even then you'll constantly be enduring anywhere from two to eight attacks for each turn you get.  

Also be prepared for muscle cramps, as the combat system leans heavily on unforgiving quicktime events.  Be prepared for the biased RNG - don't waste turns on any attack that isn't high accuracy, it WILL miss.  Don't bother with debuffs, they either won't stick long enough to make a difference or the enemies will flat out ignore them.

The nostalgia humor is entertaining, but it simply can't make up for the AWFUL combat engine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022253150', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 203, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1443271268}

VOTO:7,3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197993470007', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1455683153}
review:
Are you a 90's kid? No? Are you atleast a fan of BS 90's Kid memes? Yes? Awesome! Then this is the game for you!
Fair game mechanics, a paper thin plot, and more pseudo-nostalgic referances being force fucked down your throat than reused clips in the original Power Rangers.
I like dorky games. I like what I remember of my childhood. But there is only so much a man can take!
The game settles into it's own after a bit of play. Combat does a good job of keeping you on edge without driving you mad. Respectable number of side quests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109673370', 'num_games_owned': 669, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 827, 'last_played': 1480346964}
review:
There have been a lot of nostalgia-related computer games lately, but this is one of the ones that speaks to me most. 
This game is a must for anyone that grew up on the 80s and/or likes RPGs. It's an RPG with many jokes and references to 80s culture like The Karate Kid, Transformers, GI Joe, Michael Jackson, etc. Loved this game, start to finish!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995317152', 'num_games_owned': 784, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1439442785}
review: Filled with references and nostalgia, but no substance,  This plays a lot like Super Mario RPG but without the battle variety or charm or story or characters or,... well you get the point.  Unlike Shovel Knight and Freedom Planet, this represents the bad kind of nostalgia, the kind that just says "Power Glove" and "Skeletor" and "Captain N" until it gets old.  The game's initial presentation is nice, but its not any different mechanically from any other Paper Mario esque rpg.  And it lacks the charming scenarios and characters and presentation that you could get from similar cartoony RPG's with active battle systems.  It's initially charming and stupid in a good way, but the lack of story and fun mechanics didn't really do it for me.  Pass on this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033016365', 'num_games_owned': 1025, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1419288814}
review:
This quick game has a lot of nostalgia. Wether its taking tropes from old Saturday morning cartoons or putting stickers on your binder. (Which is used for special abilities) The game is played in small episodic chunks and it works well. 

If you are looking to spend a few hours on a lite RPG instead of devoting days and weeks to something, give this a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023246857', 'num_games_owned': 1266, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1432837553}
review:
Oh, the nostalgia! This game was made out of love for the "back in the day" shows and cartoons that we as kids watched and enjoyed the hell out of. By the way, keep in mind this was a game that did not make a lot of money and was developed with no contract or anything, it was a game made by developers who wanted to pay tribute to the past (reason why there isn't still an episode 5 available). Turn based combat sequences are carried out and you are able to use various everyday items as a weapon, a feature I have enjoyed a lot. Recommended for gamers that want to remember their childhood and have fun while doing so!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=444621493

review:
"Now you're playing with power!"
This game is short, but very fun nostalgia trip into 80s/90s, with Paper Mario-style gameplay.
Its a mobile port, but a good one. It even allows you to select PS-style button icons for QTE events! Don't expect good graphics though, it was made for mobile phones from 2009-2010.
I suggest you to consider buying the mobile version instead, if you would prefer playing this game on the go.
Devs promised 2 more episodes in addition to existing 4, but did not deliver so far. I'll keep waiting...

author: {'steamid': '76561198130920268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1434179326}
review:
Have a nice and gently laugh at that 80s/90s aura you would otherwise find a little too kitchy. The game is so full of quotes and referencies you are bound to get -at least up to a certain extent- and to feel a bit old and nostalgic with some self-awarness of the time passing by. It's a melting pot of crossed pop referencies that blend up into a school canteen soup: lines and expressions are accurate enough to get you into the mood just by themselves (I'm not a native english speaker but somehow they bring me back to the ones I once was used to), the tools you'll use are a trip in a yardsale, the end battle screenshot are shiny as they should, the music is nothing short than a Journey, the "cinematics", the main and the side plots are a collection of action films memories. It's not a gem of crazy humor in itself but mostly in the eyes of the player who picture himself and his childhood through the eyeglass of an older person. 
Moreover you can enjoy a pre-battle and in-battle tactical system that it's easy enough to get but gives you a decent rate of improvent and learning. Basically, you have to combine power-ups and buffers and the tools you use in battle, so the options are vary and not repetitive and suit the rpg concept of the game. To add more flavour (said by a very clumsy guy) the developers put into a certain number of minigames, mostly to trigger weapon and tools side effects and to charge up your attacks (I'm not using a mouse and I'm regretting it). Last but not least it's cheap. This is not a lifetime game experience but it actually gets, in a rather honest way, it's primal goal: to help you sail through a lazy saturday morning when you are in vein of a time back flip.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997801929', 'num_games_owned': 2918, 'num_reviews': 407, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1429041896}
review: So worth getting at full price if you appreciate a good game design with awesome 80s/90s references and a somewhat funny story with outlandish characters.  This also works well with the Xbox 360 controller.  I enjoyed this game almost as much as South Park: The Stick Of Truth.  In a lot of ways, the combat is better in Saturday Morning RPG.  The story is just as ridiculous, and even though I hated having to read text boxes, I feel that the lack of voices may have been a good design decision.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141636286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 723, 'last_played': 1428100554}
review: This is a turn-based RPG with a great twist. I hate the word epic as I believe it is used far to often these days but if I had to sum the game up in one word it would be EPIC! being a child of the 80's this game bring back all the great things from that time. The game is an RPG with a zesty kick, no longer will you get mindbogglingly bored getting into fights and as a result spend most of the game trying to avoid enemies, in this game it is a joy to go head on with the enemies as they all have different abilities and moves. All in all it is a refreshing change and I love it! there needs to be a option to gives games two thumbs up to give this game justice. I will recommend this game over and over again. BUY this epictatstic game NOW or forever live in the darkness of mindbending boredom.

review: Despite the fact that it is almost always on sale somewhere this is a fairly decent little romp. I can't say I'm overwhelmed with the much vaunted "humour" (and I AM a child of the 80's having been birthed in the 70's). The gameplay is nothing special either but it's good enough to be more than worth the pitiful ammount this game sells for. You could do a lot worse for a lot more cash. Pick it up, use it as filler, and you will have a little fun.

review: Quite an enjoyable RPG with lots of humorous dialog and references. There is also something really satisfying about knocking an enemy out of the battlefield with a baseball bat or smashing them over the head with a floppy disk.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997172478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1013, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1423505695}
review:
[h1]Saturday Morning RPG is a classic turn-based RPG overloaded with 80s/90s American stuff from cartoons to pop culture and breakfast cereals[/h1]

However, if you're younger and don't remember those times - you'll miss a lot of gags and references - especially since you're probably, since you're reading this, not an American living in those years either.
In this game the witty dialogues and the plot itself are the biggest attraction.

The gameplay itself is based on turn-based combat, which requires us to choose our initial attacks and react with QTEs. There is so much going on during the fights that the farther into the woods we go, the harder it is to click all those attacking buttons in time.
It will take us a while to get used to it.

Saturday Morning RPG is a treasure for old people. Who feel sentimental about their youth and would like something to remind them of it. From the humor to the gameplay everything here is very well conceived and executed - I find it hard to complain about anything - My rating is eight chocolate stars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050478086', 'num_games_owned': 1672, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1411948797}
review:
Saturday morning is a rpg with lots of nostalgia feelings from the 80s heck even in the first 5min of the game you get a reference to the power glove and how it's so bad.
But the rpg elements are really boring, notice i said boring not bad, you gather stickets and elements from the 80s to put in your notebook, select up to 5 stickers and 5 of those elements from the 80s and when it's time to battle you gotta do a QTE to scratch those tickets for the bonuses, once you're fighting is similar to a paper mario game, each item has a different attack and can be used a limited amount of times, accompanied with a  QTE for more damage, you also need to recharge your batteries in order to do extra damage which can be done in 3 different ways, tapping fast, timing, or automatically.
Battles are somehow lenghty hence why it becomes really boring in the long run, since it's the same strategy each and every battle, recharge , attack , recharge, attack , until you win.
The items attack animations are really cool though, using a carebear to shoot carelasers from your chest and such.
If you're from the 80s or are a fan of turn based rpgs you can give it a try, this game got bundled quite several times already so don't go hasty and buy the full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068118575', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1437733985}
review:
Games where the interaction consist of little more than repetively moving the joystick back and forth and pressing down the right key at the right time as fast as you could, were pretty much the dogs bollocks back in the 80s. Me and my friends used to love games like this when we were kids, playing them for hours.

However, that was almost 30 years ago. Not only are my own personal standards for computer games and entertainment higher, but so is my craving for some intellectual challenges.

As a kid 30 years ago, I'd probably love this game. As an adult today though, I consider Saturday Morning RPG to be nothing but a boring waste of time.

Whilst I respect that many people seem to enjoy and like this game, it's just not my cup of tea.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041949592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 605, 'playtime_forever': 169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1480724422}
review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a RPG Adventure  game.



[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

There are many resolution sizes available.
There is fullscreen mode and windows mode available.
You are able to play with a controller.
You are able to change the volume by each 10%
Notebook for stats.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

If you are familiar with the "Paper Mario" game, The combat is almost the same here aswell. If you are pressing the button on the exact moment. The effect will be better. Like doing more damage. Before the match starts you are going to scratch some of the stickers in order to make them activated during a fight. The faster you are able the scratch the more buffs you will get. You are able to use ability items. They will do damage and has sometimes a chance for a status effect on the enemy. You are able to explore around a little bit, which will reward you with experience. There is a Guage meter in battles, Filling this up before you are going to do an attack Will do you alot more damage!
You are able to collect stickers that are affecting/buffing you in the battles.

Has memes?
Has references from different games, older cartoons and many others.
Game is very fun.
There is a story.
Able to get experience and level up.
Breaking the fourth wall.
Music is okay.
Graphics is decent.
There are quests.
Pixelated characters with a 3D background and world.


[h1]Other things.[/h1]

Has many references from alot of things.
It is like  "Paper Mario " series.

-------------------

I Give this game a 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198157234524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1505471705}
review:
As far as the humor of this game goes, it's absolutely great. If it was in the 80s and early 90s, it's in here. That makes it incredibly entertaining, and I want more episodes just to see what other things show up. It's a non-stop run of references, like if I Love the 80s was a video game.

I like the style of the art as well, although the biggest issue is that the fighting gets a bit repetitive, and the grades for it feel a bit arbitrary. For what the rest of it has, though, I can more than forgive it that, though I feel like if I could more easily test out different weapons I'd not be as bored, but with only 5 slots, it's tough to take leaps to try other weapons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165730808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1421291227}
review: Totally rad.  It's a tribute to GI Joe, Transformers, every John Waters movie, Back to the Future, and of course the bygone Saturday morning cartoon lineups.  Pretty much every other pixel-graphics game out there uses them not for nostalgia, but because they're cheap and easy.  At least in this game the graphics actually complement the theme.  The badge system and equipment scheme familiar to many RPGs is cleverly turned into "stickers," and items stashed into a magical Trapper Keeper-style notebook.  Righteous.  There are a good bit of side quests to explore.  Some of the weapon animations are absurdly funny, and you earn steam achievements for trying out different things during combat.  Which, by the way, is a well designed mix of strategy and button mashing.  The four main story quests are on the easy side, but the arena and endless-wave battle modes are challenging.  Completionists will likely want to replay all the levels to get everything.  I'm looking forward to episode 5.  Recommended for turn-based RPG fans of any age and, definitely for every 80s kid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081211748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1550281275}
review:
I bought this game on the last day of the holiday Steam sale on a whim, and it was one of my best purchases to date! Admittedly I am the exact target audience for this game - I grew up in the 80s and still remember sneaking downstairs waaaaaayyyy too early on Saturday mornings to watch Voltron, Dungeons & Dragons, Josie & the Pussycats, etc. and nearly dying of  excitement the year we finally got an original Nintendo. Everything from the music, to the quests, to the NPC dialog perfectly captures both my real and imaginary life from that time period - I love it.
Speaking somewhat less subjectively. The episodes are short - for me that's a bonus. Each one took me 45-80 minutes for the first run through, and that was fully exploring. But that is perfect if you don't have a lot of time and want to feel like you're accomplishing something in a gaming session. Also, there is some replay value, as you get to keep all your new shinies when you replay a level, so you can experience the satisfaction of instantly obliterating a baddie that gave you trouble the first time around. But I can see how a short game would be unsatisfying to some players. But don't say it's not worth the $$. It's like, $1.50 now, and even if you pay the full $6.99 that is around $1 per hour of fun at most. If you're willing to pay even $5 for a matinee movie, you can't complain this game isn't worth it.
Also the battles, turn based, can be a little repetative - especially in the beginning. But once I had a few more weapons/defensive options/buffs I had a lot of fun playing around with various combinations.
No the graphics aren't up to Witcher 3 standard. Or 2. or 1.  Or...   80s remember? 
That said, if you've ever seen the Transformers cartoons and thought only "Ugg, this is unbearable" or can't stand music from before 1998 then maybe this game isn't for you. But anyone who had to sit through a D.A.R.E program, or rushed home aftrer school, hoping not to miss the Transformers OP please, please "risk" $1.50 (or whatever!) on this game. The psychological benefits of just the first 15 minutes alone are probably greater than your last 5 therapy session.*

*I'm not mocking therapy or people who need it! I'm in therapy! I'm just saying laughing and feeling good is good,

author: {'steamid': '76561198071753929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1420867336}
review:
This game relies more on its charm and its disctinct tone and aesthetic than its game play. The game play is quite a lot like paper mario's only less well thought out. That said, it does provide some unique and interesting ways of mixing things up a bit and keeping them fresh, like the scratch and sniff mechanic and the little mini-games you have to perform before executing most of your attacks. After a while, though, it all starts to get pretty repetative. 
As I said though, if you play this game, don't play it for the game play: play it for the humor. Play it because you'd like to take a trip to a place where '80s pop-culture has run rampent and you must stop Lord Hood (basically the Cobra Commander) because the Share Bears and the Go-Bots are depending on you. 
If you didn't understand anything I said in the last sentence or see anything close to humor in it, don't bother picking up this game. Especially for your PC or Mac.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982941845', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1455678969}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG is a classic-style turn-based rpg packed full of 80s/90s cartoon and pop culture references.  If you grew up in that era you'll find this game hilariously entertaining.  If you're too young to remember those decades, you'll probably miss all the parodies and references (you've been warned).  The episodic storyline and witty dialogue are the highlights here.

The gameplay is fun too.  It's a turn-based combat system that requires input (timed button presses, QTEs) throughout each battle.  There is a lot going on during combat, even a pre-combat buff/de-buff minigame, which can seem a little over-complicated at first.  It may take a few battles to become comfortable with the game mechanics.  Also, the difficulty can be scaled in several different ways so it's flexible for any skill level.

The only problem I had is that the pre-battle minigame is hell on your analog stick.  Luckily you can just use the mouse then grab your controller for the rest of the battle. 

Saturday Morning RPG is a great game; a real hidden gem.  Just be aware that the story and humor were designed with a specific age group in mind:  those who enjoyed saturday morning cartoons of the 80's and early 90's.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040811698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 428, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1415590477}
review:
Actually a pretty fun and amusing RPG if you don't mind some of its quirks.

+Good options for resolutions, environments look decent
+Wide variety of attacks/skills and highly customizable
+Plenty of amusing jokes/references from the past (80s/90s)
+Combat is fun and keeps you involved with timed attacks/defense
+Play with a mouse, keyboard, gamepad, or combination
+Steam Trading Cards

-Controls aren't customizable in-game and are not well-explained
-Sprites are pixelated graphics, and don't look good with the rest of the setting.
-Not as much from actual Saturday Morning cartoons as you might think

author: {'steamid': '76561198048103773', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1415057522}
review:
I want to give this game a positive review in the worst way, but I can't. Two big reasons why:

the first crime is Saturday Morning RPG is obviously imitating 90's jRPGs. While it gets the walking around the world part right, the jRPG style battles are god awful. I get the designers' decision to make the process involved with timed button presses, but they went overboard. Almost every attack relies on button mashing or QTEs. Worse is your character is so freaking weak your basic and special attacks hardly do anything to enemies so the battles drag needlessly. To be fair, there is a charge move that multiplies the damage your next attack does. Unfortunately charge is so OP I find myself relying almost entirely on it just to effectively damage normal enemies. And, of course, the charge move that gives you the best bonus is the one that involves hammering on a single button. REALLY annoying. The combat is easily bad enough that it ruins the game.

the second crime is the soundtrack is not included with the game or offered as a download. The music was co-composed by Vince DiCola. If you don't know who that is, he composed the instrumental tracks for the Transformers The Movie (also the awesome montage medley in Rocky IV which undeservely won a razzie) so Saturday Morning RPG has the exact same super cheesy 80's synth sound and its a perfect fit for the game and its theme. The OST is wonderful. I'm actually really ticked I can't listen to it!

Aside from these 2 issues, Saturday Morning RPG does everything else correctly. It crams as many sly references to 80's and early 90's Americana (including a Fruit Stripe reference) into its cliched cartoony plots that seem heavily biased towards Transformers and GI Joe (not complaining). Nostalgia is a big part of the enjoyment if you're old enough to pick up on most of it. The writing is actually good. There's a lot of awfully odd and amusing flavor text sprinkled thorughout. In fact, most of the references in the game are amusingly cornball nonsense. If it weren't for the game's awful combat system, I'd fully endorse the $7 asking price, but that awful combat system is like 1/2 the game and sucks a lot of the enjoyment out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999283440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1404977133}
review: This game is just stupid amounts of fun. Especially if you're like me and grew up watching cartoons like this. On top of fun characters and story the game play is pretty tight and the combat system throws enough in to keep things from getting stail. My only gripe is that you pretty much play through it alone, you don't get any back up and you fight the hordes of bad guys by yourself. Other than that it's a great game and I highly recomend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045882856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1415159759}
review:
Hey this game is fun.

Be aware it is not a full fledged turn based game.  In the battles there are button pushes that require timing.  So it is a bit more active, but it makes it fun too.

This game is chock full of 1980's parodies.  It's a light hearted affair, which made me think it would be too easy.  That is not  the case, while it isn't a die a lot game it is somewhat challenging.  Enough that it will make you want to pay attention to the buffs you choose.  I felt it was a nice balance and fun if you know the 80's.

I installed it on my Ubuntu system and it worked no problem.  I did have issues with my brand 360 controller and my logitech one as well.  It involves a quick button push equaling a hundred pushes which could be used to cheat.  Every battle begins with a certain action known to destroy analog sticks anyway.  So I decided keyboard was the way to go, and it worked well for the game.

The price is low because the game is short,  I got halfway through in 4 hours.  I will definitley be finishing the game because oh, did I say already, it's fun.  Get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105680429', 'num_games_owned': 5132, 'num_reviews': 572, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1412914618}
review: Ê∏∏ÊàèÊúâÁÇπÂ§öÂÖÉÂåñÈ£éÊ†ºÔºå‰∏ªÊâìËøòÊòØÁ≠ñÁï•ÂõûÂêàÂà∂ÔºåÊúâÁÇπÂÅèÂêë80Âπ¥‰ª£ÁªèÂÖ∏‰∫∫Áâ©ÁöÑËá¥Êï¨‰πã‰ΩúÔºåÊ∏∏ÊàèÊ≠¶Âô®ÁßçÁ±ªÂíåÊäÄËÉΩÊîªÂáªÊñπÂºèÁπÅÂ§öÔºåÊ∏∏ÊàèÂâßÊÉÖËõÆÂπΩÈªòÁöÑÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÂØπÊ¨ßÁæéÊó©ÊúüÁªèÂÖ∏‰∫∫Áâ©Âæà‰∫ÜËß£ÂèàÊØîËæÉÊÑüÂÖ¥Ë∂£ÁöÑËØù‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•Â∞ùËØï‰∏ãËøô‰ΩúÊ∏∏ÊàèÔºåÁªùÂØπ‰∏ç‰ºöËÆ©‰Ω†Â§±Êúõ~

author: {'steamid': '76561197980771676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 553, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1413398432}
review:
[h1]Nur der fr√ºhe Vogel spielt ein RPG[/h1]

SM-RPG (welch reizvolle Abk√ºrzung) ist ein nettes Spiel f√ºr zwischendurch. Ein RPG - wie es der Name verr√§t - ist es im klassischen Sinne: Man selbst steuert aus einer festen Drop-Down-Perspektive den Helden durch insgesamt 4 Episoden und darf sich sichtbaren / vordefinierten / vorplatzierten Gegnern auf der Map stellen. Das Spiel wechselt dann in einen Rundenkampfmodus, bei dem man - √§hnlich wie in "Southpark - The Stick of Truth" oder "Child of Light" - gewohnt mittels Befehle interagieren kann.
Die Auswahlm√∂glichkeiten der T√§tigkeiten ist aber arg klein und bleibt es das Spiel auch √ºber - Normal angreifen, Spezialf√§higkeit oder Aufladen des Schadenmultiplikators.

Normal angreifen ist meist Schmarn, also wird eine der vorm Kampf definier- und auflad-, aber im Kampf aufbrauchbaren Spezialf√§higkeit genutzt. Diese machen aber nur Sinn, wenn der Schadensmultiplikator hoch ist - wof√ºr man eine Extrarunde zum Aufladen braucht. Das Schema l√§uft also immer gleich ab: Aufladen - T√∂ten - Aufladen - T√∂ten - Aufladen - Sch√§digen - T√∂ten - Gewinnen. Dank der besonders in Episode 2 stark ansteigenden Gegnerdichte ging mir das anfangs spa√üige, aber nach ca. 1,5 h eint√∂nig werdende Spielprinzip langsam auf den Sack.

Trotzdem lohnt es sich, wenn man es konditioniert spielt, weil die wahnwitzigen Story- und Questhintergr√ºnde und der Hang zum √ºberdrehten Wahnsinn einfach zu beeindrucken wissen. Die Waffen (wie eine Floppydisk oder ein Gamecontroller, der immer wieder ein altes Atariminigame einbringt) sind einfach einfallsreich und witzig. Das Spielprinzip bleibt jedoch immer gleich - Hol- & Bringaufgaben und dann immer wieder sinnlose Kloppereien. So richtig "stark" wird man aber irgendwie leider nicht.

Hab ich aus einem Bundle und empfehle ich jeden auch so oder im Sale abzustauben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139993892', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1404697164}
review:
How many of us remember waking up early on Saturday morning when we were back in school, when the biggest question wasn't "how much sugar disguised as breakfast food can we down in a sitting", it was "what cartoons do we want to watch?"  Those were the good old days- when CBS, ABC, NBC and FOX all had Saturday Morning blocks of cartoons. 

You get to play as Marty, a guy who watches too many of these old cartoons.  His goal is to stop the forces of evil from taking over the world- and to stop them by using as many 80s pop-culture references as he can cram in his Trapper Keeper.  You can attach scratch-and-sniff stickers to your binder to give you special powers and increased stats when you scratch them, but let's face it- Marty's no Lion-O when it comes to battle.  Relying on physical attacks just won't get you anywhere- instead, you can rely on those same pop-culture shoutouts, like giant plastic playsets (like G.I. Joe's old giant carriers) and rainbow-striped zebras, and obvious knockoffs of Care Bears to do damage. 

If you remember the late 80s, you'll love all the shoutouts to cartoons that anyone born after the early 90s will never get the references to- if you were born later, you'll love the game for its playstyle- it's easy to pick up, fun to play, and it won't run you that much.  There are four episodes currently- if you count the overly short and played-up-for-cheesiness Christmas Special, and I'd like to see a fifth, if they ever decide to make one- or a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002241093', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1409850299}
review:
This game is incredibly fun, hilarious game with plenty of references to old TV shows and movies like Star Wars and such, you can play with keyboard, Xbox controller or PS3 controller so all the in game button prompts are corresponding to how you are playing. (I played this game with a Xbox controller so for the sake of this review I will using the Xbox buttons).
The combat in this game is turn based like your average olden days RPG, however it has timing aspect to it. This includes pressing A at the right time to block enemies attack so they deal less damage to you, doing small mini games in some of your spells and starting every battle spinning your joystick to get buffs that you choose beforehand in your little notepad. Some of the powers include spawning rainbows out of you to attack your enemies, playing simon says to kill the enemies and I would go over all of them but I feel as if I would be spoiling it for you if I did.
The story is broken up into 4 episodes (soon to be 5) where our hero, marty is trying to save the world from Commander Hood while trying to gain the affection of his crush, now that may sound clich√© but trust me, this story is anything but clich√©, It is incredibly enjoyable to watch play out and obviously you have dem sweet sweet side missions during the episodes which I found myself laughing at on multiple occasions.
Oh you finished the game you say, well you can also replay old episodes with your now stronger character whom you can also take into arena mode to fight stronger versions of enemies, also an endless battle mode where you choose an episode and fight endless waves of enemies from that part of the game, and of course you have leaderboards so you can show all your friends just how much better than them you are.
The only thing I dislike is the length of each of the episodes if you were to ignore all the side missions you could finish the first 2 episodes in around an hour or two, however if you are playing an RPG and not doing side missions and exploring, Then you are doing RPGs wrong, oh and you also get XP for exploring which is great.
I would recommend this game to all my friends hense why I am writing this review, so buy it today :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198116707297', 'num_games_owned': 1826, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1406066199}
review:
If you are a child of the 80's like I am and you have the slightest interest in turn based RPG's you owe it to yourself to pick this game up.  However, even if you did not grow up in the 80's I think you will enjoy this game as long as you like a good old school RPGs.

Pros:

- great dialogue that will make you chuckle, even if you don't get all the references it is relatable enough for anyone to get a laugh out of the characters in this game.

-fun turn based combat- think super mario RPG, if you never played that shame on you, you really should, but basically it is turn based but with timed button presses.  Different moves you do bring up different mini games that require timing to inflict max damage.  Also when enemies attack you, timed button presses reduce the damage dealt, the better your timing the less damage they inflict.

- lots of cool items to collect, the weapons in this game are varied and funny and range from ordinary stuff like baseball bats to some bizzare things like simon says and fruit stripes gum.  

-free DLC coming in the future, 4 episodes right now and the game will probably take you roughly 4-5 hours to finish if you do most of the side quests (you will want to, as they are generally worth a chuckle), the developer has confirmed episode 5 is coming soon which will be free, any future episodes will also be free.

-epsiodic layout gives the game a nice feel, each level is large enough on its own and riddled with secrets and side quests and the episodic nature of the game means you don't have to worry about doing any boring backtracking which is all too common in RPG's

cons

-linear character development, not a huge con but if your into branching paths and stuff like that you won't get it here, you quickly learn that magic is the best, you will pour your stats into that and wreak havoc with your flying laser discs and karate kid headbands.

Overall if you are into turn based rpg's with fun combat system and a funny story you will like this.  It is not an epic game, and it does not take itself seriously, but it is fun and you will laugh while you play it, and IMO that is what video games are all about.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113597491', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1408343955}
review: This game...MAN this game; it has the most nostalgic, ubiquitous feeling any game has ever personally given me. Now, it doesn't rely on this to captivate the audeince; the real quality lies within the QTE's. For some, this isn't a main attraction, but I believe it keeps the reflexes sharp, and who couldn't use a bit of tightening on that level? Anyway, this game manages to condense a multitude of radical 80's throwback quotes, abilities, and even that disgusting gum that had a zebra as a mascot into the fray, with positive results. I recommend this game to anyone and everyone who enjoys a hardy chuckle of a game, that can also provide a quality challenge as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032273330', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1457131604}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG is your classical turn based Role Playing Game with the feeling of the old 80s cartoons. The main character Marty has a vivid dream about the super villain Hood as he kidnaps the hero's love interest. Equipped with a magical notebook, he gets from a spontaneously appearing wizard, Marty makes his way into the enemy main base. And so begins the first episode of SMRPG.
 
Gameplay

SMRPG features the very classical RPG Systems. Top down view while travelling through the overworld, doing some quest and turn based battles when engaging an enemy in the overworld. If you don't know what a RPG is, well, you missed quite a lot of video game culture. If a battle get started you switchSaturday Morning RPG 01 to a battle screen. During the course of the game you only have Marty as playable character, so goodbye party formations. The enemy side can consist of up to three opponents with varying color scheme. Luckily the devs got every scheme unique looks and features. Your different actions in the battle consists of a normal punch, a power up move and the various tools and toys you collect in your adventure. You get stuff like a floppy disk, a transformer, or even the power of a share bear. All with varying stats and effects. For some of them you need to beat a little mini game to unlock ist full power, but nothing really difficult. The power up action is a neat little feature. You have a damage multiplier in the lower left corner, that you can increase with every action. You have three possible options for that, two of them are mini games where you either need to press the button multiple times, or in the right moment, and an option where it happens automatically. You lose a round by doing that, but you get a multiplier increase of three or four points each time, so the pay of is quite nice.

Story (Spoiler Warning)

This game is a living 80s reference. The main character Marty travels on
a hoverboard (Who can guess his last name?), transformers, Share Bears, and a villain who comes back every week with a new idea to take over the world. The game currently consists of four episodes. The first is a dream episode, Saturday Morning RPG 02where Marty gets ist power and rescues the girl of his dreams. Sadly it's only a dream and this girl is still together with the greatest jerk in school, bet, hey, at least he can keep his new powers and in the next episode he can use them against this giant death laser his arch-villain commander hood has hidden under his school and ruins the bake sale with it. With the third episode you see a little change in style, because this time you have nothing better to do than fighting giant evil transformers. And saving the city dam on that way. In episode four the devs proudly presents you the christmas special episode, where you need to save christmas and bring back all the stolen presents. (guess who did that) In the end of the episode you even see a nice surprise.

Future

Currently only four of once 20 planned episodes are in the game. The problem was that this game was first made for iOS and didn't really well there. But since it's on steam now the sales are much better and the good guy devs promised to bring out new episodes FOR FREE. Episode 5 and 6 are even in production right now. And that'S good, because there are some loose ends from a few side quests i really want to know how that's going to end.

Conclusion

Pro:
- Classical old school RPG
- many 80s references
- Entertaining story
Con:
- low content at the moment
You have a nice looking game on your hand here. If you take your time to do all side quest you can get around 5 to 10 hours of fun out of it, depending if replaying some episodes, which some side quests and the achievements encourage. The battle system works flawlessly, the story is good and there a lot stuff to collect to keep you occupied. But see for yourself, theres nothing that can go wrong with it. And if still have concerns wait for a steam sale. A 75% Off will definitely convince you to buy it.


For more Reviews visit my Blog at: http://achievementunlockblog.wordpress.com/home/

author: {'steamid': '76561198131915075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1587475456}
review: To my knowledge, I have played all avaliable episodes of Saturday Morning RPG, and have completed it in roughly just under 4 hours (but because I like the side quests and exploring, I've stuck around a bit more, it's become more than that since) and I have to say, this was well worth ¬£2! LOADS of pop-culture references, spanning from the 80s, up to present day. The fact you can collect and explore as well as it being in a TV show format, means it has alot of replay ability. I'll definitely be returning to this in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961194018', 'num_games_owned': 681, 'num_reviews': 297, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1406358842}
review:
Nostalgic references can be fun, but they can't carry a game. Saturday Morning RPG is a love letter to 80s childhood, featuring loads of references and parodies from the time period.

It features a cool take on the turnbased system, 80's charm, a fun soundtrack, but proceeds to slip into mediocrity. There's no real strategy or challenge to the combat and it becomes very repititious very fast. It's cool running over Not-COBRA foot soldiers with Not-Optimus Prime for the first 20 times, then it just becomes drudgery.

It isn't bad, but it isn't great. It's competent.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198018302427', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1405933607}
review:
It was fun, but short... but after looking around, I found that there is an episode 5 in the works. There is also an achievement that says to complete 6 different episodes.
With the ability to save anywhere I would say that this game can be casually played. If you are one to skip side quests and additional story text, you may end up speeding through this quicker than 8 hours.
There are many additional extras that may keep you entertained, endless moder and arena battle, but it you are like me and just like to play though a main story, then 8 hours are all you will get from this.
Recommended (only pay about a quid).

author: {'steamid': '76561198053116592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1405999643}
review:
Original Review

I can already tell you that although I've only played the first chapter of Saturday Morning RPG, I can unequivocally recommend it!  I got this little gem for under $3 on a Steam sale, but it's well worth it even at the full price!  The game has spot on controls, great graphics, non-stop laughs, and a fun factor through the roof!  Even if you aren't a child of the 80s, this is an amazing ride not to be missed!

UPDATE:  7/21/14

I finally completed Saturday Morning RPG, clocking  in at just over 10 hours.  The game is so good that this seemed a tad short.  However, looking at its Steam page, there will be a 5th episode released as a free update!  

So what do I think of Saturday Morning RPG now?  This is THE BEST RPG I've played just behind the Mass Effect Trilogy, and Oblivion, which are my number 1 & 2 favorites respectively!  That's saying quite a bit since I play a lot of RPG's.  I'd have to say this is even better than Might and Magic III, Skyrim, Baldur's Gate, Final Fantasy 7&10, Super Mario RPG, and Costume Quest!   

I have to say, this game is completely worth it at full price!  Don't wait for a sale!  GO BUY THIS NOW!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198139136242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1454972447}
review:
Loved this game, start to finish! As a man born in the 80s I loved many of the references to the cartoons of that era.

However, nostalgia is not the only thing this game has going for it. Nor is the fantastic soundtrack. The battle system itself proved to be surprisingly addictive, to the point where a considerable chunk of my time playing was spent in the Endless battle mode. The battle system reminded me of the likes of Paper Mario, with having only one character and emphasizing tactics over level-grinding, especially if the difficulty option is set to level the enemies to match the player.

You can generally tell if a game's retro-style sprites are a stylistic choice, or a sign of laziness on the part of the developer- the former being graphics like those of Mega Man 9 and 10, which have real effort behind them and would have been considered top-of-the-line during the period of gaming they imitate, while the latter often would be considered ugly even by early NES standards. For Saturday Morning RPG, I'd say it falls quite squarely in the stylistic choice category- I could easily imagine the sprites wouldn't look too out of place on a 16-bit era title. Your mileage may vary on how willing you are to have that merged with the 3D backgrounds, but for me it reminded me of how things worked with some PS1 classics like Star Ocean: Second Story, Breath of Fire III, and Tomba. (Yep, I got some 90s nostalgia out of it too, not just 80s.)

The buyer should be aware this game is short. Its four episodes are written to feel like episodes out of a Saturday Morning cartoon, and their length is set accordingly. The plotlines are very much self-contained, and emphasize nostalgia-related humor over deeper storytelling. I still considered it well worth the small price tag and then some (liked it enough to buy it twice, even- Ouya and PC versions!), but don't go expecting $7 to buy you a Final Fantasy-class epic. I read there's plans for two more episodes in the future, but I've no idea how far in the future.

Overall, Saturday Morning RPG is a surprisingly addictive title, well worth it for anyone with any fondness for the 80s, or who enjoys RPGs like Paper Mario that have unique battle systems that stand up well on their own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071864629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1185, 'last_played': 1440623208}
review:
This game is well made. It is clear from playing the game that it is in a league of it's own. The graphics work well for the type of game that it is - a homage to the 1980's and early 90's culture. I bought this game and didn't know what to expect. What I found was a well-made, thoughtful but fun and light game that may become my game of the year. I HIGHLY recommend this game to everyone. It was very rewarding to play this game - it was FUN. It was a feel-good experience and I just hope there is more of this game. DLC? Count me in DAY ONE!

EDIT: UPDATE - August 23, 2015 - I've started playing the game again to get achievements and complete levels. Doing that really takes the gameplay to a new level and increases the challenge. Playing the game fully takes a game that was a "quick playthrough" and turns it into a full gaming experience. 

Returning to the game after playing it once gives new perspective. The game is STILL fun, enjoyable and well made. I would still highly recommend it to others.

EDIT: UPDATE - August 25, 2015 - This game has been due for an update for the past two years. EPISODE 5 was due two years ago, but has been pushed to "summer 2015" as per the games Steam page selling the games soundtrack. It's 2015 and there is no update yet. This is important because this game has achievements and one of them is "complete 5 episodes" - and you can't do this with the current 4 episodes that are released.

As much as I love this game, other players need to know that there is an UPDATE DELAY that impacts the ability to play the game and makes 100% completion impossible.  I have posted twice on the facebook group of Saturday Morning RPG but there is no word from the developer. I will update this as needes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027026818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 819, 'last_played': 1406310298}
review:
Short review: Buy this game. 

Longer review: Buy this game, because it has a lot of elements coming together in the right ways. The gameplay has a classic JRPG feel, but still does its own thing. It's turn based, with timed attacks (and defenses). There's enough complexity to make strategy more than just selecting the same attack every time. You can select several stickers, that give combat buffs (or to your enemies, debuffs), as well as your special attacks in the form of items. These are balanced in terms of speed, power, accuracy, as well as price. One item might do massive damage, but be costly, or take a long time to be used once selected, or maybe not always hit. A big part of the strategy is selecting the best prefight equipment. 

The episodes are decent length, about an hour or so, depending on how much you like to explore and do side quests. What I really appreciated was the lack of artificial extension. The game doesn't have you backtrack, or wander around to find where you need to go. Objectives are clear, and you can always tell where you need to go by arrows on screen. It keeps the game moving quickly if you want to rush, but you're also free to explore, talk to characters, and just enjoy the environments.

While it's fun enough as an RPG, the overall atmosphere is the main draw. It lives and breathes nostalgia for the 80s (and early 90s), and anyone who spent their childhood watching Transformers, or playing with GIJoe will have an extra appreciation for it. Though, even if you weren't a kid in the US during the 80s/early 90s, you can still appreciate it. 

The nostalgia isn't forced, or bled dry. It's just there, so the game feels like it's of the era, rather than just looking back at it. It's challenging, but not frustrating, and the humor is subtle. In short, the game has charm.

My only complaint would be the lack of length. It doesn't have 100+ hours of gameplay... probably more like 10-20 until you get bored (I clocked in about 16 hours, when counting replaying the episodes, and trying out the arenas). Still, those will be pretty fun 10-20 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117844895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 371, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1405649671}
review:
A hilarious setting comprised solely of 80‚Äôs nostalgia and references that saturated teenage life at that time. Everything from key guitars to 80‚Äôs cartoons and ad campaigns make up the entire world of this RPG. The story is nonsensical and funny, but it‚Äôs also a two-sided coin in regards to its audience. 

It‚Äôs one thing to have a story take place in the 80‚Äôs and quite another to have the story entirely constructed out of 80‚Äôs Easter eggs. People who never grew up with the ‚Äúfriends don‚Äôt let friends do drugs‚Äù cartoon ad campaigns, never had to use a floppy disk, never watched ‚ÄúBack to the Future‚Äù or know what a scratch and sniff sticker is might get a little lost in the humor. That‚Äôs not to say younger audiences couldn‚Äôt enjoy it, but most if not all the jokes are intended for those who grew up in the 80‚Äôs.  

Still the game is fun and solid. There weren‚Äôt any bugs, combat was interesting and there was some obvious thought put into its funky visuals. For the price it wasn‚Äôt to short on playtime ether, I spent roughly $3.00 on this at a steam sale and several hours later I am still playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047936755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1404481972}
review: Took me a while to break down and actually buy this, but I'm glad I did. If you already know this kind of game is your thing, get it. It takes the funnest element from, Super Mario RPG, and flies it around like you wouldn't believe. The turn-based combat system allows for adding extra punch to your attack, and extra toughness to your defense by using anything from a simple push of the button at the right moment, to playing Pong from Atari to bounce a ball at opponents for a few hits. They really went crazy with it. I like an RPG that can force me into a bit of cardio for that bit of extra power. The story is simple, and still entertaining. I like all of the, 'I see what you did there,' moments as well. Anyway, the bottom line is t hat this game is a refreshing satire on all of the 80's era cartoons and games, with a little bit of 90's thrown in to boot, and it's well done. The graphics of course aren't anything special, but quite frankly my dears, I don't give a damn. It all just fits together well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000243226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 270, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1507122191}

review: This isn't for anyone who is looking for anything too serious, the RPG elements are simplistic much like the recent South Park SoT but that is good in my opinion as this type of game is about entertainment. This is a big nod to the 80's and is designed to remind you of that time, when the line between good and evil was simple and Autobots never really killed anyone. When you can pick it up on sale it's under $3 and well worth it, especially with more episodes to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992567771', 'num_games_owned': 2160, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1404158735}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG will ein RPG Spiel mit vielen Geschicklichkeitseinlagen sein das an die vielen Cartoons am Samstag Morgen erinnern soll. Der Witz dieser Anspielungen kommt dabei leider nur sehr selten r√ºber.

Marty ist ein klassischer Sch√ºler, der kaum Freunde hat und gemobbt wird, doch dann erscheint eines Tages in seinen Tr√§umen der Zauberer und √ºberl√§sst ihm ein magisches Notebook. Damit bekommt Marty magische Kr√§fte und kann sich endlich gegen seine Widersacher und seinen neuen Erzfeind Commander Hood wehren.

Die rudiment√§re Geschichte des Spiels wird in einzelnen Episoden erz√§hlt. Achtung auch wenn es den Anschein erw√§gt das Spiel sei komplett und fertig, fehlen noch immer ein oder zwei Episoden, die die Story beenden. In den einzelnen Episoden der Story muss man immer wieder die Schule, die Stadt oder gleich die ganze Welt vor Commander Hood und seinen Schergen retten, mal sind das die b√∂sen Badbots und ein andermal die bezahlten Schl√§ger der Schule. Am Ende gibt es immer einen Bosskampf und die Episode wird mit einem Abspann beendet.

In den einzelnen Episoden gibt es abseits der Hauptgeschichte viele Sachen zu sammeln und es gibt auch einige Sidequests zu erledigen, diese beschr√§nken sich aber bestimmte Gegner besiegen oder Sachen zu einer bestimmten Figur zu bringen.

Die Grafik ist einfach, verspr√ºht aber trotzdem Charme. Mir hat der Stil zumindest sehr gut gefallen. Die ganzen Charaktere und Figuren werden als 2D Sprites in einer einfach designeten 3D Welt angezeigt.

Die K√§mpfe machen Spa√ü und k√∂nnen mit dem sehr frei definierbaren Schwierigkeitsgrad auch sehr fordernd sein. Im Kampf gibt es ein Multiplier System. Man kann statt eines Angriffs einfach seinen Multiplier mit Mana aufladen, dazu kann man eins von zwei Minispielen w√§hlen oder einfach ohne Interaktion den Multiplier aufladen. Mit den Minispielen kann man den Multiplier nat√ºrlich weit h√∂her bringen als wie mit dem Standardaufladevorgang. Ein h√∂herer Multiplier erh√∂ht dann den Schaden der eingesetzten Waffen oder des Standardangriffs. Vor einem jeden Kampf kann man vorher ausgew√§hlte Abzeichen abrubbeln um f√ºr diesen Kampf bestimmte Boni zu bekommen. Die K√§mpfe erfordern viel Interaktion, viele eingesetzte Waffen, die √ºbrigens auch alle an alte Cartoons erinnern sollen, erfordern bestimmte Tasteneingaben, Angriffe der Gegner wollen punktgenau verteidigt werden um den Schaden so minimal wie m√∂glich zu halten.

Saturday Morning RPG ist ein kleines Spiel das besonders f√ºr Leute empfehlenswert ist die mal schnell ein kleines lustiges RPG f√ºr Zwischendurch spielen wollen. Hardcore RPG Fans werden unterfordert und gelangweilt sein. Die Anspielungen werden nicht bei jedem z√ºnden, man wird aber trotzdem ab und zu einmal ein grinsen im Gesicht haben.

review: This game is a must for anyone that grew up on the 80s and/or likes RPGs. It's an RPG with many jokes and references to 80s culture like Transformers, GI Joe, Michael Jackson, etc. As for gameplay, it's similar to Costume Quest or the Penny Arcade games. You wander around gathering abilities, leveling up, assigning skill points, etc. During battle, you play mini games to power up your abilities, like pushing buttons quickly, or following button sequences.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094221272', 'num_games_owned': 3116, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1402393011}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG could be really good game ... but something went wrong. 

I really enjoy playing episode one. It was something fresh, kinda fun, had cool elements, it wasn¬¥t too long and it hold my attention whole time. 

Episode two was quite good as well. I played it twice (because achievements), but i started to feel slightly unsatisfied, as I continued.

This satisfaction issue erupts in episode three. It was maybe fatigue from previous two episodes, but i was completly overwhelmed by battles. After some time it is soooooooooo booooooooooooring to fight anything and anyone here. Only thing you have to do is use same formula, and you win. Also i didnt even try to do something else because i care less and less. I felt this episode was unnecessarily long, not well paced, and some traveling points were completly useless.

I just flew over episode 4, did what i had to and quit.

Saturday Morning RPG had good beginning, but it start crumbling in later stages. It wasn¬¥t well paced, i didn¬¥t care about story at all,  battles wasn¬¥t challenging at all, and even nostalgia avoided me.

Even though i said what i said, i recommend SMRPG, for EP1 and partially for EP2.

I want to like this game so much.

[i]Grade:[/i][b] C[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198090766605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1400076680}
review:
There have been a lot of nostalgia-related computer games lately, but this is one of the ones that speaks to me most.  It has a lot of references to 80s shows I watched like GI Joe and He-Man.  Plus it has nods to other things I did back then, like putting stickers on Trapper Keepers, and chewing Fruit Stripe gum.  On the downside, I didn't love the graphics.  The low-res sprites are a reference to older video games, and I appreciate that.  However, the characters are too detailed to realistically be called "8-bit", so they didn't actually push my nostalgia buttons.  Instead, they just look blocky.  Different characters and backgrounds have different levels of detail, making characters look out of place.  Again, the graphics are intenionally bad - it's not like the programmers just got lazy.  It's just I would have preferred they presented the 8-bit references in a different way.  I've played enough modern games with 8-bit graphics, and I think this particular game would have worked better using an art style that emulates 80s cartoons rather than 80s video games.  But that's just my opinion.

Getting past the art, the gameplay is just okay.  It's your basic turn-based RPG.  Some of your special moves require minigame-like button presses to do more damage, but if you don't like that sort of thing, you can always favor the more straightforward moves when customizing your character.  It's fun, but if you play a lot of RPGs, it's nothing you haven't seen before.  The bottom line is that you're playing this for all the 80s references.  If that doesn't describe your childhood, you probably won't get much out of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041600295', 'num_games_owned': 4724, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1399136071}
review: This game is filled with funny references to the 80s and 90s cartoons and video games. The art style is pretty fun, and there seems to be a lot of modes that I haven't gotten involved in. However, it starts off for me as a full screen, super zoomed in, flashy game. Its better in a window about a 1/4 of my monitor space. It feels like it was designed to be played on a phone instead of at 1080p. However, if you don't like QTE in your RPGs, be warned that there is a lot of button mashing, button matching, and button blocking required. I like my turn based games to be actually turn-based, so I can walk away during enemy turns or be distracted by an episode on Netflix. I can't relax and play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992271177', 'num_games_owned': 759, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1399228848}
review:
The game seems promising, and has some bits parodying/referencing 80s/90s cartoons, but there is nothing that is actually terribly funny.

The combat system is obnoxious --- every fight opens with a Mario Party-style "spin the analog stick", to get your small bonuses from collectible stickers. The stickers are normally hidden items, and you can customize them out, but after a while the mini-game on every random fight gets tiresome and I don't even end up using them. The combat system itself resembles Mario RPG/Paper Mario. The items/attacks have pretty cool sound effects and animations, but requiring a handful of lengthy attacks that require quicktime events gets boring after a while.

I stuck it through 2 of the 4 Episodes, maybe it gets better, but the episodes themselves are rather short. I got the game as part of an indie bundle with some other games I was curious about as well --- I wouldn't recommend purchasing this game by itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995951257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1398796554}
review:
I felt like this game was trying very hard to engauge me with all the retro references but also irritate the crap out of me by being built on quicktime-event combat. When you go into combat, you've got the option to quick-time for 1-5 combat buffs. You'll do crap damage unless you charge first, which is a gauge quicktime. Basic attack is a gauge quicktime, to defend you have to hit 'block' *just* right. Item attacks can be rapid-press or other quicktimes. Finish combat? Your XP is based on YOUR SCORE FROM THE QUICKTIMES.

Pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978358150', 'num_games_owned': 813, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1244, 'last_played': 1397453647}
review:
Really had a blast playing this game!

I grew up in the 80's/90's so it was kinda made just for me.  At least it felt that way.  The game was enjoyable and made me laugh on multiple occasions.

Lots of button-mashing to power-up, though.  My hands tended to be sore after extended plays.

Beat the main campaign.  Will definitely come back to play endless and arena.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019205444', 'num_games_owned': 4268, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1415739140}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG is a nostalgia based RPG with turn based battles that use timing and button mashing attacks. It is a love letter to 80s cartoons, full of nostalgia.

It feels incredibly unique for a RPG with a style all its own. You get a trapper keeper that you can put stickers on it for buffs. Well a chance at buffs. You can put 5 stickers on the trapper keeper, but when a battle starts, you have a certain amount of time to scratch the stickers for buffs in battle. The battles are incredibly simple, yet take far too long. You have powers, none of which feels powerful. Each power has a limited amount of uses per battle, but it replenishes after each battle. The battle has a timeline. Depending on what attack you're going to use determines where you are on the timeline. Certain attacks are quicker, such as using the pencil put you first. When a battle starts, the enemy always goes first. No matter how many times the game bluntly tells you 'sneak attack,' they'll always attack first. It feels like a glitch. Most abilities have button timings to do more damage.

Because your abilities and attacks do little damage, you have the ability to 'charge your battery' which will become a damage multiplier for your next ability or attack. You can keep charging until its 9.9x. You have a variety of ways to charge the battery, either by spamming a button to charge it, being accurate on a slide bar or just picking a default 2.8x. I got tired of button mashing, so I just always selected the default 2.8x.

You can get more abilities by finding them or purchasing them in vending machines. You have to do something with the gold you collect. Like the stickers, you can only have 5 abilities equipped at once, but that's enough. I made it through the entire game without buying an extra ability. I would visit the vending machines, see everything laid out and there wouldn't be any descriptions. Sure I could buy the abilities and equip them to see what they did, but my first episode abilities were good enough to take me through the entirety of the game.

Most of the abilities and attacks all have a timing to them. I never really liked timing based attacks, because you quickly get the hang of it and exploit it. That's probably why other RPGs just use random chance. However, the powers can only be used X amount of times in battle. After each battle you're fully recharged. HP, MP, powers and everything. You never get any other characters, its just you against Cobra soldiers, He Man lizard men and Transformer robots.

You can block / dodge attacks by pushing a button at the right time, but even though it tells you that you defended, it sometimes damages you more than an undefended attack. I'm not sure if that's a bug. The timing with some things seems off where I know that I've missed a perfect time window, but it still counted as perfect. It is also odd hearing a boss laugh about how you fool energy attacks only make me stronger, right after I energy attack him, right before he dies after saying that. It is also odd that I can get a 'sneak attack' on an enemy where it bluntly tells me sneak attack, yet the enemies get to go first. You'll see the enemies on the map, so there are no random battles. Enemies don't respawn, so you can't really grind. The enemies and battlers aren't varied enough and eventually just feel like a chore. Another cluster of 3 soldiers, another pair of red transformers. Even moving into episode 3, you'll still find the same soldiers from episode 2.

If you die, then you just restart the battle or from the last checkpoint. That keeps you playing with no real consequence for losing. To top that off, there is an arrow that bluntly points you in the direction of your current quest. You will beat this game if you keep playing.

The overhead map uses 2D sprites on a 3D map... yep. You heard that right. The 2D 16 bit sprites on a 3D map with millions of colors. It just looks out of place. The sprites aren't that impressive, but the 3D has a good look to it. It makes me think this game was rushed or cheap. They could have done 3D modeled characters, because the entire world is 3D modeled, but nothing is animated outside of the 2D sprites.

The game has four 'episodes' and they're pretty quick within 40 - 50 minutes each. There is usually one puzzle per dungeon / episode. The puzzles show some interesting stuff and real thought put into them. If only there could have been more to keep me engaged. The final episode was a disappointment and just felt quick with no challenge, the final boss was a sad pushover.

The game takes a brief 3 hours or so to complete it. There are side quests, an endless battle mode and an arena mode. I just can't justify the $7 for this game when it wasn't fun. I've played other games that I really enjoyed that last only 3 hours, but this isn't one of them.

This game just seems rushed and shallow. More like a set of awful mini games disguised as a RPG. Battles are extremely repetitive and you feel very underpowered. You'll button mash far too much to buff yourself so you can actually damage enemies. Each attack takes way too long due to attack animations and killing animations. It also feels pretty linear even if episode 2 opens up into a less linear area, which is entirely inside of a school.

Avoid this game.
