author: {'steamid': '76561198109860236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1396782429}
review:
Monkey obsessed/convert the house into a theme park pop icons, MTV back when they knew what music was, hairspray for men, half man-half machine coppers, time travelling robots sent from the future to destroy your lineage, johnny 5 is alive, volleyball playing all american fighter pilots, welder moonlighting as an exotic dancer with a distant dream of becoming a ballet dancer, talking turtles wielding deadly weapons, cartoons that were more preachy than the bible, bible belt towns banning dancing & rock music, big hair, roller skates, panini sticker albums, scratch and sniff, balsamic vinegar, love hearts, swizzle sticks, chewits, nerds, the nerd gets the gal, playing chess with nuclear supercomputers, phoning in a sicky at school so that you can drive your best friend's father's Ferrari around for the day and then total it a few hours later, xenomorph infestations, the truffle shuffle, dating a mermaid, dating a mannequin, being aged from a boy to a man by a fortune telling machine and dating a woman 20 years your senior, Aramis, Denim, Blue Stratos, "phone home", "stick around", "I'll be back", "ADRIEN!!!", "there can be only one",  3 men finding a baby on the doorstep and raising it as there own but nobody so much as calls social services, Beetlejuice....Beetlejuice....Beetlejuice.

Punctuation.

The game is an homage to a time when things were so bad that they were good and so good that they blew our minds.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023409674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1514243590}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057071024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1477608655}
review:
This game is flat-out amazing. Almost everything in it is amazing. Honestly one of the best games I've played on Steam.

+Episodic gameplay (surprisingly replayable despite it being so linear.)
+Paper Mario-esque combat system
+Retro character models
+3d backgrounds
+Nostalgia in nearly every  moment
+Slapstick humor parodying 80's pop culture
+Many various references to 80's stuff such as a TRON disc shaped like a CD.
+Great soundtrack
-Too short
-Unavoidable combat

Overall, I give this game an 8/10. Also, to the developers: Can you please either add more episodes or add Steam Workshop/Level Creation capability? That would be a great feature to this great game.

review: The loving parody elements about Saturday Morning toons made playing it engaging and funny. I also enjoyed the mixed aesthetic; the pixelated sprites and gameplay brought some nostalgia from the 16-bit era of RPGs and fighting games.  One of my favorite things about this game had to be the music, it was thrilling and catchy and helped to tie it all together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047849599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1445231138}
review:
I really like this game, but it's hard to pin down exactly why.  Some of the things that come to mind are:

I was alive for the 80s.

The combat seems really simplistic at first, being turn-based with occasional minigames.  But it gets more interesting as you get more and varied items and try to figure out what they do, eventually developing a sort of fighting style around favored items.  It was a little easy sometimes, but by no means mindless.  Though I had a bit of an advantage--using a keyboard makes the button-mashing bits a lot easier.

At the end of a chapter it tells you whether you missed anything  (exploration, fights, items, &c) so you actually have a goal in going back to replay things other than "more XP".  Opt-out-able level-scaling means that it's not easy unless you want it to be.

There were a couple puzzle elements but they're more of a short break than a main component.

The script is humorous and slightly cheesy.  But so were 80s cartoons.

I had a cannot-play-the-game-at-all level bug.  The devs fixed it within days.

The game has four episodes now--apparently they're planning a fifth and sixth for free.

One thing I really wish they had was a better explanation of the stat system.  Or really any explanation at all.  I've mostly gotten through by just guessing at what the numbers affect.

There's an arena mode and an endless mode, but I haven't played much of either yet.

review:
Fantastic hidden gem.  Game play is fun, gamepad supported, no issues.  Very similar to new South Park game play.  Most fun I have had in a long time, and I usually wait till Saturday morning to play it just to be goofy.  Very nastalgic, when my wife saw the front screen UI she said they did a good job making it feel like a late 80's early 90's living room.  Great job overall, tons of fun, and for the price it's a must have, at least for me it was.

You will be surprised, highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000722022', 'num_games_owned': 4291, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1393968524}
review: This is a terrible port of a mobile game. It kept too many gameplay elements from the mobile version, such as scratching stickers before each battle, which works on a touch screen, not so much with a controller. The game would have been great if it was redesigned for a computer instead of keeping the same gameplay elements of the original. I would recommend playing this on a mobile device, as it was intended, instead of wasting money on a poor port.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993780180', 'num_games_owned': 2222, 'num_reviews': 270, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1392437184}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001845311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1393702228}
review:
The two games this most reminds me of as I play it is Super Mario Rpg and Costume Quest mostly in the combat and a good sense of humor.

This game is very well done with tons of 80s references like the movie Short Circuit with Johnny Number 5, the Thundercats, Back to the Future, or even an attack that involves the colorful Zebra Gum from my childhood.  Combat is smooth and actually fun to where you need to time a 2nd button press to get bonus damage or critical hits. The story is nothing to brag about so far but amusing and kept me interested.

Lots of bonus content to like an endless mode and arena.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004663985', 'num_games_owned': 2745, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1393667996}
review: Saturday Morning RPG is an jrpg that focuses on nostalgic references. The references are mainly from the 80s. If you aren't old enough you probably miss a lot of the references. The actual gameplay is that great. The combat system is a bit tedious with a lot of quick time events. If you born in the 80s or like rpg's the game is oke, but nothing special.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985114832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1561694788}
review:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OHzrUCTYolY&feature=youtu.be

Nostalgia is a powerful force and one look at what's currently on the market for gamers can attest to what a soft spot consumers have for it. The downloadable market is flooded with games that emulate everything from 16-bit RPGs to 2d platformers. Kickstarter has brought us updates and sequels to the games we grew up on and some of the key titles that defined the childhoods of 90's gamers have received HD re-releases. While some games simply play the nostalgia card to give us the warm fuzzy feelings that get us to open our wallets faster than an inebriated middle aged man at a strip joint, others use nostalgia as a vehicle for humor and personality. Saturday morning RPG falls into the latter category.
	
Following an interesting episodic structure, Saturday Morning RPG places players in the role of Marty, an average teenager who is given a magic trapper keeper by a power glove clad figure called The Wizard in order to face off with Commander Hood. It waste's no time conjuring images of Fred Savage and a certain band of real American Heroes. Each episode plays out like an episode of your favorite 1980's cartoon with some sort of malicious force attempting to carry out a destructive plan and your Hero's journey to thwart their efforts. The episodic structure is actually quite interesting, your level and inventory carries over between episodes and players can go back to previous episodes to uncover missed items and sidequests. Also there are a couple minor cases where something that your character does in one episode carries over in another. The narrative elements are minimalistic but some characters carry over between episodes creating a bit of continuity. The problem is that characters have very little personality, they instead lean too heavily on what they are supposed to reference. Players who are unfamiliar with the source material used to create these characters will find little interest in them and some of the jokes centered around some of these characters read like overused memes. 
	
Unlike most RPGs, Saturday Morning RPG doesn't dwell too much on it's narrative and in instead a bit more focused on combat and it managed to offer a surprisingly robust system for a small budget title. Aside from sharing an acronym with Super Mario RPG, Saturday Morning RPG borrows heavily from the timing based combat system in Mario's first role playing outing. Timing button presses during attacks yields greater damage and timing a button press at the last second can help players avoid major damage. Almost every special attack has some sort of mini game that requires a bit of skill and dexterity to make the most of. In addition, turns can be sacrificed in order to charge Marty up, giving him a damage multiplier. The charge function can be used in one of three ways, the first and most effective requires players to rapidly press buttons to build the multiplier, another requires timed button presses to make the most of the multiplier's potential and finally there is a charge function that requires no interaction but yields the smallest multiplier. Being able to dish out five times the damage in a single turn makes it well worth foregoing an action. Additionally, there are dozens of items and up to five can be equipped--each giving Marty a new special attack. Their abilities recall the abilities that Final Fantasy's Blue Mages are capable of learning and provide a mix of offensive and defensive skills. 
	
The final piece of the combat puzzle comes in the form of stickers and covers for Marty's magic trapper keeper. The cover can be swapped out for a stat buff and up to five scratch and sniff stickers can adorn the front. At the onset of each battle, a fixed period of time is allotted for players to scratch each one of these stickers. Doing so can further buff Marty's stats or debuff your foes. The catch is that the more rewarding the buff or debuff, the more time it takes to scratch the sticker so finding the most beneficial combination of stickers that you can feasibly and consistently activate before each battle adds an appreciable degree of strategy. 
	
The problem with this whole system is two fold, the first of which is that fact that it can make the game exhausting to play. Starting each and every battle furiously smashing our analog stick back and forth to scratch stickers then mashing the A button like a coked out woodpecker in order to gain the highest multiplier become taxing. It should be noted that Saturday Morning RPG was originally designed with phones and tablets in mind so some control input issues are not surprising. The other, more serious problem however is that the game is simply too easy. Anyone who is reasonably quick and has respectable timing will breeze through the game largely unopposed. It is completely feasible to build a multiplier in one turn and knock a boss out with your second action. There is one fight however that is an appreciable test of your skills and ability to strategize to be uncovered.
	
Rounding out the trip down memory lane, Saturday Morning RPG features a hodgepodge of graphical elements to recall games of the past. Characters are composed of 16 bit style sprites but inhabit a 3d world recalling the look of Paper Mario. The environments are rendered in simple 3D with a cartoonish aesthetic. Unfortunately the environments can appear too simplistic at times with blocky geometry and flat textures. Being a mobile device port, it's not surprising that the tech isn't up to scratch but a little more spit and polish for the PC release could have really given Saturday Morning RPG an invigorating style. Audio is generally strong however with a soundtrack composed by Vince DiCola of Rocky IV fame and Kenny Meriedeth. 
	
Saturday Morning RPG a solid and enjoyable game for those familiar with the pop culture of the 1980's and early 1990's but gamers unfamiliar with the bag from which it pulls it's gags are less likely to be tickled by it's appeal to nostalgia. Even so, the robust combat system and episodic gameplay make it really enjoyable to play and if you feel so inclined, replay. It's just unfortunate that players who want a bit of a challenge have to dig for secret boss fights to find it and that your favorite input device may fall victim to the harsh stick waggleing and button mashing required to play. Even still with a budget price, four complete episodes to enjoy and a fifth and sixth on the way, the good exceeds the bad and if you are of the right temperament, you may even find the experience totally righteous.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093145458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1393207465}
review: I was smitten with the idea of playing a JRPG style game that referenced 80's pop culture and had a mind-blowing soundtrack by Vince DiCola of Rocky IV and Transformers fame.  I was somewhat disappointed.  The 80's references are jumbled and make no sense (why would the Cobra analog exist in a He-Man inspired locale?)  Many of the weapons are just plain useless and you basically have to "power up" all the time to be effective in overly simplistic combat.  The game world itself is overly simplistic and basically just involves wandering around from fight to fight until a boss battle.  ...And the soundtrack isn't very good and only vaguely reminiscent of Vince DiCola's other work.  Did I mention that the transforming sound effect from Transformers is literally somebody making "whoosh whoosh whoosh" sounds with their mouth into a microphone?  Perhaps I've been spoiled by the quality of other indie games I've played, but this one doesn't live up to the hype.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028020795', 'num_games_owned': 6567, 'num_reviews': 502, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1392144648}
review:
First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/saturday-morning-rpg-first-impressions/

Saturday Morning RPG is an episodic turn-based RPG (self-classified as a JRPG) heavily influence by the 1980s, with a great soundtrack to match.

The game heavily emphasizes the combat aspect of the gameplay, with new fights just around the corner (literally). I was drawn into a fight very frequently and could barely navigate my way around with so many enemies. It is a great way to grind for XP, if you're wanting that kind of action. Although I didn't happen to be in existence during the 80's, I did understand most of the references made throughout my experience in Saturday Morning RPG. If you frequent the Internet and know just a little bit about pop culture, you should be fine.

The references, packaged with the game's humor and absurd writing, is where Saturday Morning RPG really shines. I thoroughly enjoyed that aspect the game and that alone could serve as the basis for my recommendation of the game. The game's combat does get repetitive, very quickly in my case, but I still managed to enjoy myself despite this. There are plenty of side quests available, adding a great deal of content to the game. The game wouldn't take that long to beat by itself, so the side quests really add value to the game as a whole.

The game's graphics were nothing too fantastic. In fact, it looks like the graphics originated from a mobile game. Most of the graphics are sprite-based, so can't really complain there. The graphics blended both 2D and 3D objects into one, large 3D environment. It took a little getting used to, haven't played a game with this style in a while, but it wasn't anything to complain about.

Saturday Morning RPG is a great effort, I really enjoyed my time with it and look forward to completing it in the near future. And for $7 too!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989129610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1469151463}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG is everything it promises to be when you see the store page on Steam. It is a love-letter to the pop-culture of the 1980s and has no apologies to offer for that. As an RPG game, it both is amazing and disappointing at the same time. The gameplay itself is surprisingly deep and something I can not recommend enough, but at the time, it is very short for RPGs (I finished it in about 8 hours) and the overall story falls very flat.

If you look back fondly on an 80s childhood, this is probably a game you should get your hands on, as you will enjoy it. If not, the strengths and weakness of this RPG kinda makes it a toss-up. But for the price, it just might be worth giving a shot anyway.

The full review is available at http://redsectorshutdown.blogspot.com/2014/02/saturday-morning-rpg-pc-review.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198032325631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1392584614}
review:
As the title  implies, the game makes many  pop-culture references from the 80s, that anyone born after 1990 would most likely miss. The best feature of this game in my opinion is that it is divided into episodes. Each episode has a self-contained story arc, and allows you to replay sections of the game you enjoy, whiel ignoring ones you don't. I would like to see a similar mechanic in more mainstream games. 
 The gameplay itself is very simple, and involves powering up, and mashing buttons. However, some attacks have amusing animations, such as the BB gun(you'll shoot your eye out, lol). Also, there is only one playable character, Marty. 
 All in all, This game is worth the six bucks just for the humor. For those looking for a hard-core rpg, probably not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019826070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1392606444}
review:
I have been playing this game for a bit, and I have to say that it is excellent. While loaded with "retro" humour and pop-cultural references, the game also manages to keep a more or less coherent plot to it. The turn-based combat harkens back to Super Mario RPG on the SNES.
Anyway, I'd say that overall if you are a fan of 1980's and early 1990's cartoons, video games and movies, you'd probably get a kick out of this game. I certainly am.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035826801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 643, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 896, 'last_played': 1404330086}
review:
It's decent. More of a humorous RPG/adventure than a traditional (indie) RPG. Humorous adventure games that have references and jokes in them don't usually interest me, but yeah. I gotta say the battle system is pretty good but the user interface is terrible.

The game becomes tedious after episode 3 in my opinion because the many enemies take too long to kill - the achievements require you to kill insane  amounts of enemies. The game takes about 10 hours to complete (I was afk so it took me a bit longer) and about 70+ hours to get 100% achievements.. the achievements not being worth it, if you ask me.

Of course, you can always rush the episodes and make the game last much less by not doing sidequests.

I'd give it a 8/10 - it's certainly not for everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117218372', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1455133346}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008411723', 'num_games_owned': 1759, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1001, 'last_played': 1605020462}
review:
I was looking forward to this game ever since I saw the trailer for it but it still managed to surprise me. Much better than I expected. The game is hilarious and is full with references to 80s and 90s. I laughed out loud so many times. The feeling of nostalgia is really strong in the game but it's not the only selling point. Story is nice. Dialogue is funny. Soundtrack is fantastic! Specially soundtracks that play during battles are kick-ass! Another stong point of the game is the combat. It is turn based, but you can actively block and power up. Combat never feels boring thanks to all the different items you can use. Explosive discs, burning basketballs, a pack of unicorns and so many other awesome things.

Game is episodic and there are 4 episodes available right now. 5th and 6th episodes are currently in developement and will be free DLC. Beating these 4 episodes took me 7 hours but you can replay them without getting bored because some missions have different endings depending on your choices and like I saide before, combat never gets dull.

Like all the things I mentioned above weren't enough, the game is only 7 dollars. This is a steal in my opinion. Strongly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063587281', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 225, 'playtime_forever': 779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1627153635}
review:
There are a lot of references here... be prepared young ones otherwise you may not really get it.

The graphics are kind of weird, we have 3D back grounds with 2D character models which gives it a bit of a charm, reminds me a bit of Grandia but over all I believe the enemies could of been drawn better. I'm also not a big fan of how the main character looks either but whatever, could of added a life jacket to his wardrobe. :P

Either way, it plays like Super Mario RPG so if you're old enough to be familiar with that game then you know what to expect.. a timed attack and defense system basically. Trial and error is required to get the timing down, so don't expect to be a pro right off the get go as encounters with new enemies is like learning how to play all over again.

The Dragon Ball Z power up system is a bit of an oddity and almost a necessity so don't neglect your magic stat.

Be warned that the game is indeed unfinished and the last couple episodes have yet to be patched in... so don't go too hog wild maxing your character out as there will be no experience for you to gain when those episodes get released.

Overall it's a decent game for the money spent. It's a good nostalgia trip and fun in stints. You can save wherever you wish so if the episodes are getting too boring or long for you, you can take a break and resume right from where you're standing.

6.5 / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198051825287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1433010151}
review:
Bad:

The user interface was slightly unwieldy; sometimes the tooltip would block the ability to click other items.

Some of the items don't deal the damage the tooltip might suggest(i.e. five star damage items doing 4-5 damage whereas 1 star damage items doing double, not talking about multi-hit items obviously).

Combat was frustrating at times, especially if an opponent puts up a shield just before a big hit, nullifying more than 50-100 points of damage with a ~10 health shield. On that note, if you get a moderate to severe debuff to your accuracy, you may as well restart the battle since you are pretty much next to guaranteed to not hit .


Good:

Quests were intuitive with their direction and were easy to understand and undertake as a result. 

Lots of different items and builds to experiment, with some degree of flexibility with changing builds via stickers. 

Being able to repeat episodes allow you to make different choices and do quests/obtain items one may have missed. 

Overall: 6.5/10

Points deducted mainly for game balance and minor UI issues. 

For such a cheap price, do buy it for an enjoyable game with some quirks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015033652', 'num_games_owned': 1087, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1422847130}
review:
This game is loaded with references and throwbacks to pretty much everything from my childhood. It triggers a lot of nostalgia, and I am really enjoying it. It doesn't just throw things at you from the 1980s, the entire writing style is done like cartoons were done back then. The first episode actually has your girlfriend captured by the villian so he can force her to marry him. It's goofy and absurd with little bits of gameplay thrown in.


That said, if you take all of that away... This is not a great game. The controls are really not well explained and you have to figure out how to use each new attack all on your own through trial and error. The menu system is not very well designed, and before you can even adjust your graphics settings you have to start a new game. Maybe this is intentional, since most games you played back then required you read everything from the instruction book. Or if you rented the game and it didn't have one, you'd have to figure it all out yourself. 


I still recommend this game because in spite of the gameplay issues, I'm enjoying it. And that's really all that matters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041818023', 'num_games_owned': 4216, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1391647673}
review:
While I did enjoy the sense of humor this game has, I still found it to be rather boring.  The battles are tedious affairs, with every enemy getting two attacks to my one, it's a matter of sitting around waiting for my turn, especially when faced with three opponents.  The rest of the game is mostly walking around repetitive caves/hallways, moving from battle to battle.
Low budget, low-res games can be every bit as entertaining as AAA titles, and I have enjoyed many hours with them.  However, being low budget or indie is no excuse for being boring, so I would give this one a miss.  Well, I already bought it, but you know what I mean.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961521733', 'num_games_owned': 4427, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1391577502}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960804536', 'num_games_owned': 663, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1391417805}
review:
Pros:
- Funny
- Awesome nostalgia for people familiar with 80's-90's
- Combat is fun and interactive
- Easy to get into and very straightforward in controls

Cons:
- If you like extreme mechanical play, this game is definitely not that.
- Younger people might not get the references that this game relies heavily on for it's humor.


I picked up Saturday Morning RPG (SM RPG) because I was born in the mid eighties and fondly remember the Saturday morning cartoons of my youth.  The game gave me a lot of nostalgia and I personally found it hilarious.  I think that the comedy might fall flat on some of the game's references though for people not familiar with the 80's - 90's.

The game is pretty easy to pick up and get into as it plays like an older RPG of the NES/SNES days.  With that said do not expect any crazy mechanical game play.  I think the most mechanical thing I had to do was try to hit a ball a la old video game pong style.  The fighting was interactive though, with rapid button presses to charge attacks and meter based attacks.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone familiar with the 80's and 90's and that are looking for a fun and funny RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038684598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1459750477}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983550854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 565, 'last_played': 1391321624}
review:
This game kinda came out of nowwhere for me.  Other than me picking it up in a bundle recently right before it was greenlit, granting me a steam key, the only thing i knew about it was it was its snazy name and just another indie with seeming lofty goals.  So its got exploration, hilarious side quests, engaging turn-based-combat with all kinds of crazy weapons and powers some requiring button pressing/mashing.  Most of these you find in game, but some are quests rewards or can be bought in vending machines.  The music is much better than most games in the retro-indie realmn for me at least.  There's even a handful of puzzles, etc on the decent size levels.  Right now there are 4 separate episodes with more to come.  Your character progresses though each and you can replay keeping your powers/equip.  Also each episode you pretty much have free reign of the maps once you pass certain story parts and i'd say each episode is about 1-2 hours if you do most of the battles and quests.  

Lastly what puts this game on top is the insane amount of references to 80's, 90's movies, tv-shows, and other pop culture.  While i love Obsidian(the developer) and have no love for South Park and that soon to be released RPG may end up being good, but somehow i think this gem is already better, and only dicks have the gall to charge $60 out the gate for a comedy/non 3d RPG.   I would say this game is worth full price though definately don't hesitate if it goes on sale

author: {'steamid': '76561198112875635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1391297838}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026782701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1418794445}
review:
If you are like me and born in the late 70s-early 80s and 'Merkin (I say that because I dont know how well 80s american pop culture references are going to translate to other cultures. If you live in a county that imported a lot of american stuff back then, you might like it too), this is pretty much a must have.

You find yourself grinning at 80s stuff you totally forgot existed, and a lot more you remember. Just off the top of my head (and Ive only been playing for 20 mins) Lisa Frank style trapper-keeper with scratch and sniff stickers on the cover, rainbow brite-like belt, michael jackson's glove, people saying radical and bogus, fruit stripe zebras, care bears, the battle summary page looks like those strange bar graphs that were on the back of Transformer's/GI Joe boxes (or a card inside)...I could go on.

But underneath of all the stuff that will make someone in the vicinity of 30 years old remember their childhood is a well made RPG. 

The controls are fluid and intuitive and although you are given a brief tutorial, anyone who has played video games will know how it works.

Theres a lot of button press/joystick wobble quicktime events in battle to keep you from just mindlessly selecting fight or a special skill over and over, simple things any gamer recognizes. Hit the button at the correct point, tap the button repeatedly, wobble the joystick and so forth. T

heres also plenty of awesome stuff you can get to have different attacks in battle, all of them amusing (IE chewing fruity gum causes a heard of rainbow zebras to run out and trample your enemy, a sword you hold over your head ala He Man causes a beam of light to hit someone). Also you can collect scratch and sniff stickers that you have to wobble the joystick before battle to "scratch" that provide powerups, the more you scratch in the alloted time, the more powerups.

The graphics are bright and colorful, and remind me of Paper Mario. And to top it all off, the soundtrack is really really good. Or should I say "radical", har har.

The game is episodic like a cartoon show, with 4 episodes included and a fifth to be released for free soon. If you fondly remember your 80s childhood, grab this game. You wont regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015843023', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1391598696}

author: {'steamid': '76561197985136814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1632365316}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980391269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1391147714}
review:
My video impressions on the game:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T-auXo2mVHM

Every now and again a game pops up and surprises you. This was one for me. It is a very casual JRPG game oozing with 80's nostalgia. It features very unique abilities such as a 3 1/2 inch disk slap to the face or a care bear stare. Pair that with active defending and a couple other surprises during combat makes it quite enjoyable. 

The game is broken up in to 4 current (5th to be released later TBD free of charge) episodes. Each features a different story line and location. The first episode was about 30-40 minutes and the second was about 2 hours taking my time.

The gem with this game is best equated to the book, "Ready Player One" where the nostalgia drives the story. For someone my age (31) or older, you will love the references from times past (ie: stay off the adult BBS's or The Wizard with a Power Glove). 

Do yourself a favor and pick up this game. It's the price of a value meal and will provide you with quite a bit of entertainment, just don't take it as a hardcore JRPG, because that would be doing it all wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036876899', 'num_games_owned': 2682, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1473293198}
review: Think Costume Quest gampeplay wrapped in a 80's coating and you get Saturday Morning RPG. Even if you weren't born in the 80's or remember a lot from that timeframe, It won't detract from the experience (as long as you know who GI Joe and Transformers are, you're good to go). You just won't get a lot or most of the references (which for me, being born in 81, love the references) . If you don't like button mashing or quicktime events (a lot of the attacks and defense use it), you probably won't like this game. I recommend this for anyone who liked Costume Quest, is looking for a fun time waster and or were born in or remembers the 80's (even those who don't).

author: {'steamid': '76561198032654665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1697605687}

author: {'steamid': '76561197992515597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1391099698}
review:
A quirky homage to classic turn-based RPGs and cartoon/movie pop-culture of the 80s'. Amazing graphics and fluid game mechanics will either make this game a nice coffee break or your latest addiction.

+ Tried and true turn-based RPG system
+ Borrows many cultural references you may be familiar with or remember fondly of
+ Cartoonish humor will make you laugh out loud
+ Features gamepad support for that extra nostalgia kick!

- Short and sweet
- Not recommended for people adverse to quick-time events and button mashing

author: {'steamid': '76561197985072747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 436, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1391353125}
review:
Genre - Western Nostalgic JRPG
I played a couple of episodes this on the ipod touch and I loved it because of the massive nostalgia/humour factor. It is actually fun to play with many weapons types and subtle tactics to use to win fights. Please bear in mind that this was a phone app originally and came to Steam via Greenlight so it is not a state of the art game. If you are in your 30s though you will definately find something in this game that brings a tear to your eye either of laughter or a memory of your youth...

author: {'steamid': '76561197965158774', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1391785632}
review:
I like to joke that Saturday Morning RPG is my favorite game on Steam that I have worked on - (because it's the only game I've worked on so far that's on Steam). So, obvious bias aside, I will try to review this the same way that I review other games: by aesthetic appeal.

The main aesthetics this appeals to are Sensory, Fantasy, Narrative and Discovery. Challenge is also there depending on how you set the difficulty in game and how much you are concerned with acheivements. There's also a huge nostalgia factor for anyone that grew up in the 80's or 90's.

For those who like 80's music (pop/rock and video game/cartoon soundtracks) you will really enjoy the soundtrack that Vince DiCola and Kenny Meriedeth have composed.

If you enjoyed games like Super Mario RPG(and Paper Mario Series), Earthbound(Mother Series), Pokemon, Final Fantasy (Particularly 1-9), Costume Quest, or other JRPGs you should give Saturday Morning RPG a try. Also I suggest it to fans of 80's and 90's music and pop culture. If you enjoy humorous games (like Double Fine games) this is worth checking out. If you are on the fence and can't decide if you would like it you can try the full first episode for free if you have a tablet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025100160', 'num_games_owned': 3313, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1455311054}
review: I don't know what would have to be wrong with your childhood in order for you to not enjoy the game. The music is brilliant, the references to everything 80's is really well done, and basically everything is done with so much love for nostalgia that there's nothing here that I can hate on. If I had to complain about anything, it would be that I can't get enough - at only 4 episodes long with about 40 mins gameplay each, its suitable, but makes me want more - hopefully some extra episodes will be available soon. But it has enough content for me to really enjoy it at a pretty decent price. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198079555685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1412208543}
review:
Saturday Morning RPG is a love letter to 80s nostalgia while at the same time playing homage to the timed-hits style battle system that has shown up before in RPGs. While I wasn't an 80s kid so I was never the biggest G.I. Joe or Transformer fan, I do know a lot about the pop culture of the time and I'm a huge fan of films from the decade.The real draw here was the game's battle system to me. I'm a huge Super Mario RPG fan, and this game draws inspiration from the series that follow it up: Paper Mario. It's also been used in Costume Quest (which the game is more similar to in design), and will even be in the upcoming South Park: The Stick of Truth. So as a fan of the genre, I felt it was nesscary to toss down the cash on it.

 And I enjoyed it. The game isn't the best RPG I've ever played (of all time...ever), but it's the writing, humor, and references that made me want to keep playing. Now, I've heard people saying this is a short game. Well, not really. You aren't going to beat this game quickly unless you skip all the side-quests and head straight from point A to point B. I don't suggest this. You'll miss out on a lot of a fun events, like when you find a Mogwai-esque creature and have the choice to feed it and get it wet before giving it back to Phoebe Cates herself. There IS a point around the third episode where the battles started to feel repetitive, but that soon went away as I found myself smashing Transformers with a freakin' axe. Not everyone is going to like it, but there are enough options in battle to keep situations fresh if need be. Better healing options (I didn't find a single GREAT healing item in my run) and more PCs (or a Paper Mario-esque helper) would have spiced up the battles, but if you're a fan of this type of battle system then you'll enjoy it.
 
 You'll spend almost 5 hours with the first four episodes of Saturday Morning RPG. Another five more if you go back for achievements or try a hand at the other game modes. And for $7, it's in a good price range where a blind buy isn't risky if you're a fan of the genre and have just a little knowledge of the 80s. It's not the best RPG of all time, but it's a great indie effort and I'm always happy to see more of these.

 (7/10)

 Recommended If You Like:

 Paper Mario
 Costume Quest
 80s movies, cartoon, and general pop culture

author: {'steamid': '76561197969268136', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1391072934}
review:
Video Review:
http://youtu.be/A-yd80JwfxE

Saturday Morning RPG is an episodic turn based RPG with an art style modeled after an 80's or 90's cartoon/comic.  The game takes place in a boys dream where he explores the world on his skate board and fights off enemies to save the girl.  The script is deliberately cliche and has lots of vague references from the era.  For me the big let down was the combat, it just wasn't fun.  The attacks consist of either quicktime events with on screen button prompts or timing a button press with a cursor moving along a meter.  The player can also charge up for bigger attacks but this mechanic is another event requiring a button press timed against a meter.  With the style of combat, despite 5+ hours of gameplay, I can't recommend Saturday Morning RPG.

EDIT (2/4/14): Updated the gameplay time to 5+ hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087864882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1631145915}
review:
This game was a pleasant suprise.  It touts the throwback to the 80's pretty heavily and it delivers without being just one name drop after another.  The combat system seems balanced but will definately get repetative, and you may find yourself choosing skills not based on what they do but based on the minigame (which tend the be pretty uninspired) or lack thereof.  Episodic game play is an interesting choice though I'm really not sure how much replayability this game will give you would be grinding or achievement hunting.

Overall it won't blow your mind but then again not many things in the $5 range will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038546620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1398728195}
review: This game is better then I expected. It's got that nice classy arcade graphics with that 80's cartoon twist. I understand the references even though I was not born in the 80's. It has a lot of creative RPG elements in the game which I didn't expect so much. If you are a big RPG fan, I would defintely recommend getting this game. It's fun and I could go on for hours. :) 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198056880915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1588545867}
review:
Fun game a lot of 80's nostalgia and solid RPG. It's 5 bucks WTH else can you do for 5 bucks thats this much fun? Cheaper than an hour of Asteroids at an arcade.

Keep all your powerups in a trapperkeeper. Multipliers are scratch n sniff stickers. One of the weapons you turn into optimus prime and semi roll over the baddies.

Works well with a controller.
